Would the soundtrack include The Rolling Stones? Would there be roles for Bill Murray, Jason Schwartzman and Owen Wilson? Would it be hip? Would the comedy have a gentlemanly sophistication and even be wilfully exclusive? Would it trade in emotions but feel distancing at times? Of course, as anyone familiar with Andersons films will know, the answer to all these questions is, yes. So it turns out: this is an animation, but its also a Wes Anderson movie. The difference is that its light on its feet compared to the heavy machinery of The Life Aquatic or the ponderous comedy of The Darjeeling Limited. Its also a kids film, which allows Anderson and his gang is there another director so collegiate? to have fun. Anderson himself voices a fey estate agent, and the film has the pace of a caper. What remains to be seen is how audiences, especially children, will react to the jolty, bristling look of stopmotion animation in the age of CGI and digital 3D. The loving, handmade, purist look of the film, reminiscent of Michel Gondrys The Science of Sleep, sees towelling as fields, cellophane as water and cotton wool as smoke, and will probably excite adults more than their kids who will be more taken by the constant, restless unfolding of the plot. Elements that, in turn, grow a little tedious if youre a grown-up. Dahls book was a short, sharp affair illustrated in pen and ink by Quentin Blake, whose drawings dont have much bearing on Andersons version; his colour palette takes its cue from the autumnal hues of fox fur. The main characters in Dahls book were Mr Fox himself, a dapper chap trying to protect his family from danger, and his foes, three ciderswilling farmers called Boggis, Bunce and Bean. Anderson and co-writer Noah Baumbach (who directed The Squid and the Whale) have fleshed out the story so there are more characters (Dafoes jive-talking rat is genius) and the Fox family has more personality. Mrs Fox (Streep) is the voice of reason to her husbands impetuousness, while their son Ash (Schwartzman), a needy, moody teen, is pitched against a kungfu- kicking cousin, Kristofferson (Eric Chase Anderson), who comes to stay. Mr Fox, voiced so appropriately by George Clooney, flits between human behaviour (buying a house, starting a career) and animal instincts (stealing chickens, attacking his food). The push and pull between the tame life and the wild one is the unifying theme. Its all very transatlantic the setting and baddies are English; the animals are hip Americans. This is one crafty fox, in every sense. By Dave Calhoun

version.name: Case 39
version.review: When parents attempt to kill their child, its either theyre crazy or the childs a demon. In this case, social worker Emily (Zellweger) finds out a little too late.
version.property: NC16 - No children under the age of 16

version.name: The Box
version.review: A couple, Norma (Diaz) and Arthur (Marsden), get their buttons pushed by a disfigured stranger who presents them with an offer to die for.

version.name: Astro Boy
version.review: Based on the cult manga series by the god of manga Osamu Tezuka, this American version boasts the voices of a whole bunch of A-listers and a ton of CGI.

version.name: An Education
version.review: A beautiful young girl, named Jenny (Mulligan) plans on going to Oxford University. But she gets lost when a generous and handsome man (Sarsgaard) sweeps her off her feet and on top of the world. No one ever said life was easy.

version.name: Amelia
version.review: We cant decide which is hotter, Hilary Swank as Brandon Teena in Boys Dont Cry or Hilary Swank here, as the first woman to fly solo across the Atlantic Ocean. However, it is agreed that Swank is one of the few actresses with that innate ability to play women born to break conventions.

version.name: A Christmas Carol
version.review: Director Robert Zemeckis uses the motion-capture techniques developed in his previous film, Beowulf, to re-spin Charles Dickens Christmas classic with an all-star voice cast.

It has become customary to bid the year adieu with at least one big-budget apocalyptic epic. 2012 based on the supposed Mayan calendar prediction of Doomsday will see the same well-known monuments crumble, but through the plight of an academic researcher (Cusack) and his ex-wife (Peet).

version.name: The Informant!
version.review: Matt Damon gives a movie stars performance in The Informant! all moustache, oversize specs and eventual bald pate. His character, Mark Whitacre, is a real-life corporate sad sack, a manic depressive who blew the whistle on a price-fixing conspiracy at the agri-industry conglomerate Archer Daniels Midland. The only problem was that the bipolar Whitacre kept changing his story: as the truth became more malleable and labyrinthine, the execs own embezzlement sins came to light, and he served eight years in federal prison. Damon plays the movieland version of the man as a cartoonish collection of tics and digressive internal monologues. Its an approach that calls to mind Richard Attenboroughs wide-eyed, Elmer Fuddian menace as the serial-killer protagonist of 10 Rillington Place. But theres something crucial missing, a sense of empathy and experience that would make the actors surface acrobatics seem less of an awards-baiting stunt. Director-cinematographer Steven Soderberghs indifference to the material is palpable and of a piece with his deathly dull output of late. It hardly matters if the subject is Vegas thieves (Oceans Thirteen) or Che Guevara (Che) Soderbergh just shows up and does some purposelessly sterile image making, as if he were a disembodied tech-head shooting a demo reel on next-day deadline. The Informant! is one of his ugliest works, photographed on the RED digital camera system in such a way that depth of field is flattened into backlit brown mush. Only composer Marvin Hamlisch brings his A-game, contributing a frenzied, perpetually upbeat score that burrows deeper into Whitacres psyche than anything else in this black-comic blunder. By Keith Uhlich

version.name: Paranormal Activity
version.review: Arriving on a wave of carefully orchestrated viral hype, Paranormal Activity lacks the conceptual elegance of its obvious precursor, The Blair Witch Project. The movie invites us into the home of a couple (Featherston and Sloat) conveniently saddled with the same names as the actors who play them. Katie suspects a haunting, so in whats now a time-honoured tradition, theyve grabbed a camcorder and elected to film everything. While superior to inept would-be Blairs like Open Water, Oren Pelis horror flick often has the feel of a film-school exercise in which the object is to wring maximum suspense from rudimentary tools. Still, there arent many movies that have the power to scare you with the sound of a creaking door, and its hard not to admire the way Paranormal Activity makes a virtue of simplicity. The opening scenes, which suggest nothing so much as a mumblecore horror flick, are eye-gougingly boring and slapdash but thats the point. In its most effective steal, the film makes brilliant use of a stubbornly fixed camera: as we wait, trapped with the tripod in Micah and Katies bedroom, wondering what happened downstairs, its easy to forgive the movies crudeness. By Ben Kenigsberg

version.name: The Sun Also Rises
version.review: This movie is a polyptych of interconnected stories in different time-zones, shifting between a Yunnan village, a campus and the Gobi Desert. Like most Chinese movies, it's a complex tapestry of madness, mischief, lust and revelations.

version.name: The Shining
version.review: This classic by Stanley Kubrick is based on Stephen King's novel of the same name. In the movie, author Jack Torrance and his family become residents of the Overlook Hotel in the Colorado mountains. Strange events begin to occur when Jack's son Danny sees gruesome images powered by a psychic force called 'The Shining'. Suffering from writer's block, and with the demons of the hotel haunting him, Jack has a complete mental breakdown and the situation takes a sinister turn for the worse
version.property: M18 - No one under the age of 18 admitted

version.name: Love Me Again
version.review:
Migo (Pascual) returns from the stifling city to the fresh air of Bukidnon to reclaim the family ranch that was lost after his fathers death. While on the business trail, he chances upon his childhood sweetheart Arah (Locsin), and promises to reclaim their love as well. Hell have to convince Arah first, though. In Tagalog and English with English subtitles.
Love Me Again trailer (YouTube)

version.name: Spread
version.review: Unsurprisingly, Kutcher plays a sexual grifter in the Hollywood Hills who lures in posh prey with good looks and attitude all for the love of money. His cons go to plan until he meets his match in a waitress/seductress (Levieva).

version.name: Shorts
version.review: Be careful what you wish for Thats the theme of this kids flick in which the towns young ones must save the town from itself (and the adults) with a magical rainbow rock.

version.name: Poker King
version.review: In this Rounders (1998) hopeful, two poker heavyweights take Texas hold em from an online hobby to a profiteering pursuit. But when the two schemers square off in a championship, who will prevail as the poker king?

version.name: Paris 36
version.review: A French musical, this film aims to tug at heartstrings nostalgic for Paris and the good ol days when the manager of an out-of-business theatre (Jugnot) gathers his fashion-savvy friends to save the theatre, his future and his son. In French with English subtitles.

version.name: Paper Heart
version.review: Comedianmusician Charlyne Yi embarks on a road trip across the US to navigate her way through romantic cynicism part documentary, part mockumentary.

version.name: Pandorum
version.review: This sci-fi thriller unravels the tale of two men (Quaid and Foster) who awaken to the darkness of what seems to be an empty spacecraft, but they dont remember what events led them there. As they try to put the pieces together, they realise to their horror that perhaps its not the end of the world they should fear; its what comes after.

version.name: Paintball
version.review: When a group of corporate executives sign up for a weekend adventure, the thrill turns deadly as live ammunition is thrown in with their extreme game of paintball.

version.name: New York, I Love You
version.review: Didnt Martin Scorsese, Francis Ford Coppola and Woody Allen make this movie 20 years ago? The idea of building an omnibus film around a major city is itself flawed; its like saying, Do whatever. Some of the directorial roster has searched for NYC-specific anecdotes, but the only surprise is that the movie saves its bickering Brighton Beach couple (Wallach and Leachman) for the end. Segments range from beautiful- but-incoherent (Kapur) to funnybut- stupid (Ratner). By Ben Kenigsberg
version.director: Jiang Wen, Mira Nair, Shunji Iwai, Yvan Attal, Brett Ratner, Allen Hughes, Shekhar Kapur

version.name: The Message
version.review: Its 1942, in Nanjing (Nanking). Japanese spies gather a group suspected of assassination attempts, but the harsh questioning goes awry in this spy-vs-spy flick when a Chinese codebreaker begins a dangerous game of cat and mouse. In Mandarin with English subtitles

version.name: Merantau Warrior
version.review: This action-packed foreign film plays out like an Indonesian version of acclaimed movie Ong-Bak (2003): a young man (Uwais) leaves his rural town and adolescence for the big, bad city this time its Jakarta where he saves a girl from human trafficking but then must fight for their lives in a jaw-dropping action sequence. In Bahasa with English subtitles.

version.name: Love Happens
version.review: Let this rom-com help you help yourself. Self-help author (Eckhart) attempts to take his own good advice for love.

version.name: Invitation Only
version.review: Five friends receive an invite to a fancy gala party. They cant imagine it was meant for them, but they go along to live out their dreams. That is, until dream turns to nightmare, and now their only wish is to survive. A slasher thriller. In English, Mandarin, Hokkien with English subtitles.

version.name: Halloween II
version.review: Rob Zombie goes out of his way to differentiate the second film in his rebooted Halloween series from the first. This is most noticeable in the grubby, grainy 16mm visuals that act as a squalid conduit to the headspace of Laurie Strode (Taylor-Compton), sister of seemingly indestructible psychopath Michael Myers (Mane). Now living with Sheriff Lee Brackett (Brad Dourif) and his daughter Annie (Danielle Harris), Laurie has no inkling of her lineage outside of the subconscious: shes tortured primarily in dreams, and Zombie opens with a doozy that pays explicit homage to the original Halloween II while bettering it in just about every respect. When his heroine wakes up in the real world, however, the writer-director starts losing his footing. Lauries story holds interest thanks to Taylor-Comptons intense dedication to the role, especially when the characters feral brother comes calling. But a side plot involving Michaels former psychiatrist Sam Loomis (McDowell), now an egocentric celebrity author, weighs down the proceedings with limp satire of our media-addled age. Zombie remains committed to showing how violence lingers with, and perverts, all who are touched by it, yet his carnivalesque approach often undercuts his very real empathy. He panders to the cheap seats whenever hes not being scary By Keith Uhlich

version.name: Haeundae: The Deadly Tsunami
version.review: A geologist notices that the Sea of Japan is displaying similar activity to the Indian Ocean at the time of the 2004 earthquake, creating a mega tsunami that is headed straight for Haeundae and at vacationers who are enjoying a peaceful summer day. In Korean with English subtitles

version.name: Earth
version.review: Five years in the making, this full-length documentary (based on the BBC TV series Planet Earth) tracks three animal families as they struggle with the changing environment.

version.name: Darah
version.review: On a road trip, six friends stop to help a small girl whos lost near the highway. The unsuspecting hitchhiker leads the car full of friends into her mothers macabre designs that end in dinner and death.

movie.name: Cloudy with a Chance of Meatballs

version.name: Cloudy with a Chance of Meatballs
version.review: In this animated adaptation from a kids favourite, it doesnt rain cats and dogs, it rains meatballs and macaroni.

version.name: Capitalism: A Love Story
version.review: Michael Moore once again analyses whats wrong with big, bad corporate America this time in the plummeting terms of last years economic downturn.

version.name: The Blue Mansion
version.review: In this local production, Asias richest man dies mysteriously but returns as a ghost with unfinished business. A whodunit ensues when two eager detectives chase leads and suspects, including his three children. Read our feature on the director Glen Goei.

version.name: April Bride
version.review: A drama about a young lady whos due to be married but then diagnosed with late-stage breast cancer. In Japanese with English subtitles

version.name: Amalfi
version.review: The scenic setting of the Italian coastline is the backdrop for this otherwise haunting tale of a little girl gone missing. In Japanese with English subtitles.

version.name: Taking Woodstock
version.review:
As Ang Lee films go, Taking Woodstock is relatively painless. When he isnt reaching for lofty, award-baiting heights (Brokeback Mountain) or being deathly, soul-sappingly dull (The Ice Storm), the infrequent pleasures in the directors work tend to rise to the surface. This adaptation of a memoir by Elliot Tiber, who was instrumental in organising the 1969 peace and love concert, is most rewarding when it abandons narrative altogether. The centrepiece sequence, in which protagonist Elliot Teichberg (Martin) takes an acid trip with two VW-van hippies (Paul Dano and Kelli Garner), is as beautifully constructed as the delirious murder scene in Lust, Caution and the windswept skip through the desert in Hulk. It also resonates with a profound sense of possibility and regret one of the few times when it doesnt feel like Lee and his screenwriter, James Schamus, are looking back at these events from a mock-enlightened perspective. The movies worst passages condescendingly play on our modern-day awareness: a peripheral character reveals that people are charging for bottled water; concert organiser Michael Lang (Groff) makes a closingline mention of this awesome Rolling Stones concert thats in the works. Such willy-nilly referencing negates the films effectiveness as a period piece and calls attention to some of the more questionable omissions. Seems its okay to have a sassy, gun-toting transsexual (Schreiber) dispense self-actualising bons mots to Elliot while conveniently ignoring the real-world Elliots prominent role in the Stonewall Riots. Lee and Schamus make history blandly palatable; in the process, they rob the times and the people theyre portraying of their complexities. By Keith Uhlich
Taking Woodstock trailer (YouTube)
version.property: R21 - No one under the age of 21 admitted

version.name: Space Station 3D
version.review: Narrated by Tom Cruise, this film will beam you 354km above Earth and into space where one of sciences greatest engineering feats awaits you. Space Station 3D documents the ups and downs of the scientists who put together this modern marvel.

version.name: Bears
version.review: Whether its the grizzlies in Alaska, the polar bears from the Arctic or the black bears of Montana, this documentary contains awe-inspiring footages of this oft-hunted mammal in all its natural glory. Oh, and we checked. Big, burly and hairy men didnt make the cut.

version.name: Little Shop of Horrors
version.review:
In the basement of Mushniks Skid Row florists, weedy shop-boy Seymour (Moranis) pines for bubbly-blonde shop-girl Audrey (Greene). But the basement is also home to a strange and unusual plant, a growing, bloodthirsty demon determined to devour mankind. Its hard to pinpoint just what makes this surreal saga such a delight. Theres the music, a wonderful doo-wop score from the off-Broadway hit based on Roger Cormans 1960 cult classic. There are veteran comedians (Murray, Candy, Belushi). Theres Steve Martin as The Dentist, Audreys biker boyfriend, a happy-go-lucky sadist who nearly steals the show. And finally theres the plant, a 50ft jiving, root-stomping vegetable from whose 49ft lips comes the voice of Levi Stubbs of The Four Tops. Though Frank Oz will be damned for changing the plays original ending let them eat carrots this wild and witty musical is great fun.
Steve Martin as the Dentist

version.name: Call of the Wild 3D
version.review: In this reinvention of Jack Londons classic, nine-year-old city girl Ryan Hale (Gade) unwillingly ventures into the cold wilderness of Montana to spend time with her grandfather (Lloyd). At first sour, things take a turn for the better when she forms a bond with a wild dog named Buck, and Ryan has a change of heart.

version.name: The Ugly Truth
version.review: Katherine Heigl has been the best thing in many an American rom-com; the frequently miscast Gerard Butler is often the worst. So the pair cancel each other out in this battle-of-the-sexes romp. Heigl is Abby, a single, uptight TV producer keen to boost her daytime shows ratings. What she didnt have in mind was a sexist relationship guru but thats who her boss hires. In swaggers Mike (Butler), a TV host well versed in macho banter think Tom Cruise in Magnolia, only less funny.
version.property: NC16 - No children under the age of 16

version.name: Sorority Row
version.review: A typical all-girl pyjama party where one dies and the others decide to keep it a secret. Thats until a fan of I Know What You Did Last Summer decides to give the girls something to scream about.

version.name: I Love You, Beth Cooper
version.review: Based on the novel written by ex-The Simpsons writer Larry Doyle, this rom-com opens at a school graduation. Valedictorian Denis Cooverman (Rust) declares his love for his high-school sweetheart while insulting half of the graduating class, including a bully, a party girl and a jock in the process.

version.name: Funny People
version.review: Judd Apatow makes his most personal project yet, as Adam Sandlers world-conquering stand-up comedian finds himself stricken with a fatal disease, and trains up-and-comer Seth Rogen to be his successor.

version.name: Gamer
version.review: In the near future, a brilliant recluse invents an ultra-violent first-person shooter game in which humans control other humans. Butler plays the guy who has to maintain his score in order to keep his family alive and save the world from virtual carnage.

version.name: Fame
version.review: Nearly 30 years on, the original Oscar-winning film gets a noughties makeover with fresh faces and happy feet.

version.name: Dance Flick
version.review: In another spoof from the Wayans brothers, a hip-hop street kid meets a ballerina whose Juilliard dreams fall to pieces when her mother dies while on the way to her audition. Dont lose count as the movie pokes fun at Fame, High School Musical and Twilight.

Instead of playing a kind-hearted hobbit, Wood stars as a kind-hearted stitch-punk doll that comes alive in a post-apocalyptic world ruled by killing machines. Produced by Tim Burton (Corpse Bride) and Timur Bekmambetov (Nightwatch), this film uses CG animation but maintains the texture of a stop-motion production.

version.name: Inglourious Basterds
version.review: You get the feeling with Inglourious Basterds that Quentin Tarantino desperately wants to put away childish things. Nor is he hiding the fact. Not only is Brad Pitts closing line of the movie This may well be my masterpiece, but Inglourious Basterds is, a lot of the time, a little more restrained, a little quieter than weve come to expect from films like Death Proof and the Kill Bill double header. We say a little because much of it is not quiet at all: when the music comes, albeit less frequently than usual, its loud; when the deaths occur, theyre gruesome, even sadistic; when the plot kicks in, its pure fantasy. Thats all fine, and Tarantino is mostly smart enough to let his usual, entertaining extravagances serve the story rather than the other way around. The film, which flits freely between French, German and English, takes us through five chapters. First, in 1941, we see Nazi Colonel and Jew Hunter Hans Landa (played by Austrian actor Waltz) discover and kill a Jewish family in France; only the youngest daughter gets away. Then were introduced to the basterds, a notorious gang of eight Jewish-American soldiers who, while deep under cover, roam Nazi-occupied France, murdering German soldiers and collecting scalps as they go. Theyre led by a Tennessee goodtime boy, played by Pitt, yet despite a lot of pre-publicity concerning his role and that of his basterds, theyre not on screen a great deal. Pitts performance is lively, but hes upstaged time and again by Waltz, whose performance lends sly comedy, cruel charm and tension to some of the films best scenes. For the final chapters we leap to Paris in 1944, where the disparate storylines collide. Shosanna Dreyfus (Laurent), who fled the Nazis, is now running a cinema that screens films by Riefenstahl and Pabst (although she also manages to slip Clouzots Le Corbeau into the programme). Young Nazi private Frederick (Brühl), whose gun-toting heroics are being immortalised in a new film produced by Goebbels, takes a shine to Shosanna and the German command decides her cinema would be a great place for the premiere. Both Shosanna, fuelled by revenge for the death of her family, and the basterds, presumably fired by their Jewish ancestry but avowedly only by bloodlust, decide that the premiere is their opportunity to strike. Unsurprisingly, perhaps, Tarantino takes the history of cinema more seriously than he takes the history of Europe. References to movies are everywhere: Michael Fassbenders British spy (who has an amusing, Drive Strangelove-like scene with a superior, played by Mike Myers) used to be a critic for a magazine called Films and Filmmakers; Shosannas cinema allows for references to, and discussions of, various directors; and Frederick wonders aloud whether he prefers Chaplin or French silent actor Max Linder. But then, as ever with the director of Reservoir Dogs and Pulp Fiction, you could say that his films are more about the movies than anything else; not least because Tarantino obviously relishes the chance to take one of the most well-documented periods in history and make it his own. To some extent, he does that very well. We recognise his style so clearly now the extended, know-it-all dialogue, the tricky gunplay, the pop-cultural nods and manages the period adaptation well. Theres even a Mexican stand-off à la Reservoir Dogs and a character who says the word nigger a staple of Tarantinos films. Even if he says it in French.

version.name: Moon
version.review: We know that Duncan Jones is David Bowies son. But more importantly, is his feature debut any good? The answer is a resounding yes, judging by this 1970s-sci-fithrowback, which, for a space movie about the knock-on effects of future technology, is unusually thoughtful, good-looking and well acted. Sam Rockwell is Sam Bell, a nervous lone astronaut on the moon where, at some point in the near future, a corporation is mining Helium-3, now the source of most global energy. Its Bells job to manage this operation in the company of a sympathetic robot called Gerty (one of several nods to Stanley Kubricks benchmark 2001: A Space Odyssey). When we first meet him, Bells three-year stint is almost complete, but hes tired and unhinged symptoms, no doubt, of solitude and having to communicate with his wife and young child by taped messages as the satellite is broken If that last fact sounds a bit too convenient, thats the point: all is not what it seems. Jones has created a credible theatre in which to stage a meditative play on isolation and identity within the bounds of wild fiction, the edges of which are curiously blurred. Less is more in Jones eye: he knows that big ideas can be lost amid noisy gestures, so keeps his drama within the confines of a few rooms, with only the odd, more poetic moment unfolding outside on the moons surface. As the film goes on, early ideas about loneliness segue into a more troubling study of corporate exploitation and even heres a biggie what it means to be human, when a second Sam Bell (a clone also played by Rockwell) appears and shakes up all perceptions of whats going on. The film is not entirely logical as Jones famous father would no doubt say, its a space oddity but it raises pleasing questions and looks beautiful.

version.name: Year One
version.review: Set at the dawn of humanity (sort of), a time of hunter gatherers, peasant farmers and idol-worshipping Sodomites, Year One wants to be seen as a freeform, knockabout trawl through Biblical history, perfect for an undemanding Saturday night.

version.name: Whatever Works
version.review: Some of Woodys best films are inspired by women like Diane Keaton, Mia Farrow and Scarlett Johansson. It is no wonder, then, that this film starring Larry David as a nihilistic New Yorker doesnt quite work. Boris Yellnikoff (David) enjoys lamenting the meaninglessness of life. The only person who seems to enjoy listening to him is a young and naive Mississippi runaway named Melodie (Wood). When the relationship starts to show promise, so do her parents efforts in locating her.

version.name: Vengeance
version.review: One of Hong Kongs most prolific directors gives you gore and more in this race-against-time thriller about a father (played by French actor/musician Hallyday) who avenges the death of his family.

version.name: The Soloist
version.review: The Atonement director doesnt quite hit all the right notes with this piece starring Foxx as a gifted homeless New York musician and Downey Jr as the reporter dying to tell his story

version.name: The Proposal
version.review: To avoid deportation to Canada, a New York book publisher (Bullock) bribes her assistant (Reynolds) into marrying her.

version.name: Orphan
version.review: After the tragic loss of their unborn child, lovely couple Kate and John adopt Esther, an orphan oozing with saccharine sweetness. Well, thats until she morphs into the child from hell.

version.name: Merantau
version.review: A young Indonesian man leaves his idyllic kampung and moves to Jakarta to make a name for himself. Instead, he ends up homeless and on the run after saving an orphan from a bunch of European human traffickers.

version.name: Management
version.review: Dopey Zahn (Reality Bites) makes it his mission to court the chirpy Aniston (The Good Girl, Office Space) across state lines in this romantic comedy. Both main actors create cringe-worthy humour and awkward moments you wont want to miss.

version.name: Imagine That
version.review: Olivia is a girl who has a harried financial executive, named Evan (Murphy), as a father. It takes her imaginary friends giving Evan tips on how to juggle his time between his job and his kid to make him realise hes a bad father. Imagine that.

version.name: Food, Inc.
version.review: First, there was Eric Schlossers Fast Food Nation, a documentary that has been referenced so many times while deciding whether or not to order McDonalds. Here, director Robert Kenner comments on Americas troubled food system, from its industrial farming to its poor farmers who get bullied by big corporations. These lifting the veil types of celluloid provide evidence that may deter you from consuming mass-produced food. If it doesnt, at least youll be more informed the next time you order that juicy burger with golden fries.

version.name: District 9
version.review: Based on a short film by the director and produced by Peter The Lord of the Rings Jackson, District 9 (or D-9) is an area where extraterrestrials are kept and treated like refugees. It is also where the worlds most wanted man is hiding, and with him, the secrets of alien technology.

version.name: The Final Destination
version.review: This fourth installation of the popular series stars a bunch of teenagers trying to escape death after a terrifying accident on the race tracks.

version.name: Diary of a Sex Addict
version.review: As the title suggests, this film charts the sex life of a beautiful and liberated 28-year-old French woman.

version.name: The Damned United
version.review: Master impressionist Michael Sheen heads up this new film from up-and-coming Brit director Tom Hooper about the late, great football manager Brian Clough and his 44-day stint in charge of Leeds United in the 70s. Based on a bestselling novel by David Peace, the film charts the story of how Clough (played by Sheen) rose up the ranks to transform minnow sides such as Derby County into Division One champions, but was always in the shadow of Leeds boss, Don Revie.

version.name: The Cove
version.review: A hit at the recent Sundance Film Festival, this documentary goes deep and uncovers the horrifying reality behind one of televisions best-known animal characters, Flipper the dolphin.

version.name: Coco Before Chanel
version.review: Audrey Tautou stars in this lavish biopic of famed fashion designer Coco Chanel. Based on the novel by Edmonde Charles-Roux.

version.name: Brothers Bloom
version.review: Ruffalo and Brody are Stephen and Bloom, orphaned brothers who have spent their lives moving from foster home to foster home, town to town ripping off the locals with elaborately plotted stings.

version.name: The Boat That Rocked
version.review: This film pays homage to the days of offshore radio in mid-60s Britain. A kind of musical comedy, Nighy plays the ships captain with Seymour Hoffman as the radical DJ.

version.name: Bandslam
version.review: A new kid in town blessed with a gift for music catches the attention of the campus sweetheart and forms a band. Look out for a cameo by David Bowie.

version.name: Forever Fever
version.review:
A musical comedy set in the late 70s about a grocery store employee who enters a dance competition in order to get his girl and a brand new Triumph motorcycle. A homage to Saturday Night Fever and actor Bruce Lee, Adrian Pang plays the unwilling hero and soulful line-dancer.
In Hokkien and English with English subtitles Where: National Museum of Singapore Gallery Theatre When: 11 Jul; 11.30pm Costs: $8 (excluding SISTIC fee). This screening is held in conjunction with this years Night Festival

version.name: Public Enemies
version.review: Acclaimed director Michael Mann assembles a band of A-list actors including Bale and Depp alongside new kid on the block Tatum to play cops and gangsters in this big-screen adaptation of Bryan Burroughs book Public Enemies: Americas Greatest Crime Wave and the Birth of the FBI, 1933-34.

version.name: Overheard
version.review: Dont be fooled by the gruesome poster of a mutilated ear caught in a rat trap; this isnt in the same vein as Hostel or Saw. In this thriller, three cops trained in surveillance learn incriminating secrets about a listed company and its manipulation of the stock market.

version.name: Obsessed
version.review: There are four important lessons youll learn from this Fatal Attraction-esque domestic thriller. If youre a corporate bigwig (Elba) and some leggy blonde temp (Larter) starts talking to you, run away; shes probably a crazy b*tch who will stalk you. If your receptionist is a borderline-offensive gay stereotype, he will gab away important expositional information. Unless you are impervious to falling chandeliers, dont piss off Beyoncé Knowles ever. Finally, dont think that exploiting female paranoia and the promise of Knowles throwing punches are enough to make up for your unabashed B-movie hitting the skids at the halfway point (David Fear).

version.name: Here
version.review: A filmmaker visits a mental hospital and attempts to document the lives of its staff and patients. This film is inspired by an experimental treatment that involves the video recording of patients who are later made to watch and analyse their own delirium.

version.name: The Haunting in Connecticut
version.review: Clichéd but oddly satisfying horror flick. Tom Huddleston

version.name: Fifty Dead Men Walking
version.review: An informant is unearthed and kidnapped by the IRA in this true story based on Martin McGartlands autobiography. Ben Kingsley stars as McGartlands (played by Sturgess) British handler.
version.property: M18 - No one under the age of 18 admitted

version.name: Autopsy
version.review: Fresh from this years After Dark Horrorfest, the main crux of Autopsy takes place in Mercy Hospital. After a road accident, a group of fun-lovin teens find themselves seeking help from a bunch of crazed doctors and nurses. The only problem is this medical team isnt in the business of alleviating pain and suffering; instead, they inflict it. If you love hearing the screams of good-looking boys and girls, and seeing lots of blood, then youll definitely like this cut.
version.property: R21 - No one under the age of 21 admitted

version.name: Aliens in the Attic
version.review: The scramble to keep kids entertained over the summer months continues with this underwhelming spin on E.T.: The Extra-Terrestrial and Gremlins. Dragged off to a remote mansion for the summer months, precocious teen Tom (Jenkins) and his self-obsessed sister Ashley (Pearson) uncover a devious alien plot to launch a worldwide mind-control invasion from their loft. Theres not a great deal to recommend, aside from a few decent one-liners, some inventive anti-gravity slapstick and a brief, but enjoyably bonkers, remote-controlled kung-fu battle between one of the kids and Toms brain-zapped granny. But such fleeting charms are largely outweighed by an unexceptional script, a brace of shabby performances (from both kids and adults) and some dismal CG effects: the aliens appear almost transparent, like animated transfers barely clinging to the screen. Aliens in the Attic will probably prove an effective distraction for undemanding pre-teens; their parents might find it more of a chore.

version.name: Sea Monsters: A Prehistoric Adventure
version.review:
If you want to get to the bottom of these ancient sea creatures, this documentary which uses a combination of animation and re-creations is your ideal ticket.
Where: Singapore Science Centre When: Through Jul; various times

version.name: Van Gogh: Brush with Genius
version.review: Take a journey through the mind of one of the greatest post-Impressionist artists in true IMAX fashion. Trip on passionate brushstrokes of infinite colour, from the striking yellow cornfields to the deep blue of the sky.

version.name: The Singing Thief
version.review:
Taiwanese actor Jimmy Lin Chong plays a former cat thief-turned-cabaret singer who gets framed for a burglary he did not commit. While figuring a way out of this mess, Lily Ho, a beautiful heiress, appears out of nowhere and their worlds collide.
Where: National Museum of Singapore Gallery Theatre When: 27 Jun; 8pm

version.name: Reflections on Love
version.review:
Made just before Wonderwall, Massot celebrates the frivolity and beauty of Swinging London.
Where: National Museum of Singapore Gallery Theatre When: 28 Jun; 4pm

version.name: Wonderwall
version.review:
Trippy and exuberant, colours of orange, gold and red fill the screen as an eccentric academic (Jack MacGowran) peeps into the decadent sex life of his next-door neighbour Penny Lane (Jane Birkin). The film also features a soundtrack composed by mystical Beatle George Harrison.
Where: National Museum of Singapore Gallery Theatre When: 28 Jun; 4pm

version.name: Gimme Shelter
version.review:
The Altamont movie, and unless you get off on violence accompanied by music played loud and raw, something of a bummer. If you love the Stones, youre likely to be irritated by the fact that the camera stays on Mick Jagger for virtually every frame; if youre keen to understand why the notorious murder took place and what responsibility the musicians should admit to, youre left with a vacuous look of shock and confusion on the singers face. Still, it is a reminder that the 60s were not entirely about love, peace and limp liberalism. by Geoff Andrew
Where: National Museum of Singapore Gallery Theatre When: 27 Jun; 4pm

version.name: Monterey Pop
version.review:
A distillation of the 1967 International Pop Festival in California, this is quite simply one of the best rock concert films ever, thanks not only to great performances towards the end things really start cooking, with Janis Joplin, Otis Redding and Jimi Hendrix but also to the way it sums up the spirit of the Summer of Love while never appearing sentimental. Hang on to the end, however, when a small Indian man appears nursing a sitar: Ravi Shankars exhilarating 25-minute finale is the best thing in the entire movie by Geoff Andrew
Where: National Museum of Singapore Gallery Theatre When: 27 Jun; 2pm

movie.name: Dolphins and Whales 3D: Tribes of the Ocean

version.name: Dolphins and Whales 3D: Tribes of the Ocean
version.review:
At first glance, dolphins and whales seem like an unlikely choice for the 3D treatment, since the ocean doesnt offer a lot of the necessary depth cues youve got the swimmers against a characterless background of water. But the first time a camera cruises down the side of a whale, that objection falls away. The narration (read by Daryl Hannah, sounding oddly like Laurie Anderson sans irony) falls into a repetitive structure for each species (theyre beautiful, theyre endangered, repeat), but as educational conservation films go, its pretty effective by Hank Sartin
Where: iWerks @ Singapore Discovery Centre When: Through Jul; various times

version.name: Up
version.review: In Pixars latest 3D film, Docter (Monsters Inc.) tells the story of a 78-year-old balloon salesman with a bout of wanderlust. Carl Fredricksen (Asner) is retired and instead of staring out the window, he ties many small balloons together to form one big balloon. One big enough to lift him, his house and everything in it.

version.name: Transformers: Revenge of the Fallen
version.review: Regardless of whether the Autobots or Decepticons reign victorious, were thankful for this live action version of the much-loved cartoon, notwithstanding a plot that suggests the beginning of civilisation started in ancient Egypt with robots.

version.name: The Taking of Pelham 123
version.review: Adapted from the 1973 thriller novel by Morton Freedgood and based on the film of the same name made a year later, this 21st-century version boasts Denzel Washington as the cop against a group of hijackers, led by John Travolta.

version.name: State of Play
version.review: See our review of State of Play

version.name: Monsters vs Aliens
version.review: Dreamworks animated sci-fi offspring centres on the gigantic misfortunes of Susan Murphy, a feisty young thing with a crush on TV weather-dork Derek. When a meteorite strikes their wedding ceremony, Susan is affected by fallout and grows into a 50ft chick with attitude. Shes taken to a secret underground facility where she meets her freaky co-stars, BOB (a gelatinous blob), Mr Cockroach, Missing Link (half-fish, half-ape) and a hare-brained maggot called Insectosaurus (Derek Adams).

version.name: Man on Wire
version.review: See our review of Man on Wire
version.property: NC16 - No children under the age of 16

version.name: Land of the Lost
version.review: Based on the 1974 TV series by Sid and Marty Krofft, Will Ferrell plays a zealous paleontologist who finds himself in an alternate world inhabited by prehistoric creatures.

version.name: Ghosts of Girlfriends Past
version.review: McConaughey stars as Connor Mead, who is single but not looking for love. A happy and committed bachelor, Connors trail of broken hearts come back to haunt him when his dead uncle (played by Michael Douglas) decides to send him a message from beyond the grave in the form of Connors jilted girlfriends.

version.name: Fighting
version.review: See our review of Fighting

version.name: Duplicity
version.review: Clive Owen and Julia Roberts unite for the first time since Closer in this spy caper from Tony Gilroy, the director of Michael Clayton. The pair star as erstwhile lovers working for rival companies. When they are both assigned to spy on the other company, the pair decides to team up and instigate the ultimate corporate sting on their respective bosses. Sounds a little like Mr & Mrs Smith minus the smoking guns and assets.

version.name: Drag Me to Hell
version.review: An ambitious loans officer divests an elderly lady of her property and ends up cursed by the now homeless old sorceress. A seer is contacted to help reverse the spell, but things spiral out of control.

version.name: Blood: The Last Vampire
version.review: Post-Twilight, and the Crouching Tiger, Hidden Dragon producers give you Blood: The Last Vampire. A member of a covert agency sworn to protect mankind, female vampire Saya hunts down demons in Japan.

version.name: The Young Victoria
version.review: Emily Blunt (The Devil Wears Prada, Sunshine Cleaning) plays the eponymous queen, whose nasty marriage to Prince Albert (Friend) drove her to seclusion.

version.name: The Uninvited
version.review: Not a remake of the sturdy Ray Milland chiller from 1944 but a surprisingly restrained version of the stylish K-horror smash A Tale of Two Sisters (2003), The Uninvited may strike even viewers who dont know the original as disarmingly familiar. A thriller in which Dads new girlfriend probably killed Mom and will stop at nothing to prevent that discovery? Its almost charming to see directors make one of those. Almost. The movie hardly plays fair, and Elizabeth Banks is an unconvincing gorgon, but Emily Browning is as adorable as the concept itself (Ben Kenigsberg).
version.property: NC16 - No children under the age of 16

version.name: Tokyo Sonata
version.review: See Reviews.

version.name: Terminator Salvation
version.review: If the movie is as good as its trailer then Christian Bale wont be the only reason to watch the fourth instalment of the sci-fi saga. Set in post-apocalyptic 2018, Bale stars as John Connor, the man fated to lead the resistance against the machines for the survival of his kind.

version.name: Star Trek
version.review: The original crew of the USS Enterprise battles Romulans from the future in the 11th Star Trek film. JJ Abrams (Lost, Cloverfield) directs and we follow James T Kirk from his first day enrolling at the Starfleet Academy.

version.name: The Ramen Girl
version.review: After being dumped by her boyfriend, an American (Murphy) finds herself wandering the streets of Tokyo. When she stumbles upon a ramen shop, she falls in love with the noodle and persuades the chef to school her.

version.name: The Meerkats
version.review: Watch as a family of meerkats go about their daily business amid the beautiful landscape in and around Tswalu Kalahari, South Africa.

version.name: Ghosts of Girlfriends Past
version.review: McConaughey stars as Connor Mead who is single but not looking for love. A happy and committed bachelor, Connors trail of broken hearts come back to haunt him when his dead uncle (played by Michael Douglas) decides to send him a message from beyond the grave in the form of Connors jilted girlfriends.

version.name: X-Men Origins: Wolverine
version.review: This comic-book prequel from the director of Tsotsi sees Jackmans terminally narked, adamantiumskeletoned mutant Wolverine seeking revenge against Sabretooth for killing his girlfriend.

version.name: Sunshine Cleaning
version.review: In this dramedy, Adams and Blunt play slacker sisters who fall into a very peculiar gig of cleaning up crime scenes, which eventually leads to a bright future off the couch and in business.

version.name: Notorious
version.review: As mainstream hip hop becomes ever more predictable, so do the biopics about its stars.

version.name: Magique!
version.review: A young woman raises her only son on an isolated farm. When the circus comes to town, the boy invites two clowns over for laughs. Once the funny business is over, romance blossoms between his mum and Baptiste (possibly the funnier out of the two clowns).

version.name: Knowing
version.review: In this ominous thriller, Nicolas Cage plays a father and professor whose son stumbles upon a time capsule with a cryptic message, which Cage conveniently figures out. Father and son, along with reluctant Diana Wayland (Byrne) daughter of the Doomsday prophet work together to save the... Well, you know how these end-of-the-world scenarios pan out. Enjoy.

version.name: Killshot
version.review: After playing a teary, rundown wrestler, this time Mickey Rourke hunts people in witness-protection programmes as a sharpshooting hitman.
version.property: NC16 - No children under the age of 16

version.name: Jonas Brothers: The 3D Concert Experience
version.review: Like their fellow tweenie sensation Hannah Montana, the boys are the ideal stars to get the three-dimensional treatment their sworn chastity making them at once safe and unattainable to little girls. Drumsticks and guitar picks are tossed into the audience, the brothers gym-flip across the stage, and crucially, there are close-ups of their faces. Aaaargh!

version.name: The International
version.review: Money men are the new villains in this timely thriller, which sets the rumpled integrity of Interpol agent Clive Owen and the pinched determination of US investigator Naomi Watts on the trail of skullduggery when the IBBC hires a 'consultant' (read: hitman) to cover its tracks. The quest for truth and justice involves a familiar parade of shady meetings, car chases, punch-ups and a truly spectacular shoot-out inside New Yorks Guggenheim, though the increasingly scrambled plotting doesnt quite measure up to director Tom Tykwers slinky, elegant handling of it.
version.property: NC16 - No children under the age of 16

version.name: Henry Poole Is Here
version.review: Empty platitudes about the healing power of religious faith give shallow meaning to the story of a depressed atheist (Wilson) whose house is declared a shrine when the face of Jesus appears on its façade.

version.name: Friday the 13th
version.review: From Marcus Nispel, director of the half-decent The Texas Chainsaw Massacre remake, comes a thoroughly indecent re-imagining of Sean S Cunninghams formula-fixing slasher movie: psycho killer slays obnoxious, promiscuous college kids.
version.property: M18 - No one under the age of 18 admitted

version.name: Crossing Over
version.review: The style of Robert Altmans ensemble-movie format was deployed to mixed reviews in commercial movies like Crash (Paul Haggis) and Babel (Alejandro González Iñárritu). It seems that the format has become the montage solution to plots that involve several characters with their own distinct conflict in a shared storyline or narration. In Crossing Over, we see immigrants from different countries doing whatever it takes to achieve legal status in Los Angeles.

version.name: Coraline
version.review: The notion of pairing Neil Gaimans Coraline with stop-motion maverick Henry Selick was an inspired one a perfect peanut-butter-and-jelly combo for goth teens.

version.name: 17 Again
version.review: This film picks up the child-in-an-adults-body theme witnessed in Big, Freaky Friday, Back to the Future Part II and 13 Going on 30. Matthew Perry plays the unsatisfied adult Mike ODonnell who works at a pharmaceutical company. While saving a mysterious janitor from drowning in the Los Angeles River, ODonnell emerges unscathed, but as his 17-year-old self.

version.name: Let the Right One In
version.review:
This Swedish movie lacks the romanticism of Bram Stokers Dracula, the teenybopper appeal of Twilight and the action-packed sequences of Underworld. But this is a good thing; the films barren landscapes and lingering shots are all it needs to haunt audiences. And we praise director Tomas Alfredson for having crafted one of the most memorable films about a vampire in love.
Eli (Leandersson) is a 12-year-old vampire who moves into a new flat in a Stockholm suburb with her caretaker. When she meets Oskar (Hedebrant), a pale blond boy at the mercy of a group of bullies, Eli falls in love. The two exchange tender moments together; when apart, the young girl stalks the streets and feeds on unsuspecting townsfolk. From the sound effects (the actual heartbeats of the child actors) to the locations, the Swedish director keeps it organic and minimal; the few locations used in this film include a desolate snow-covered playground and Elis one-bedroom apartment, with its peeling wallpaper and treasures collected over 200 years.
In the films most grotesque scenes of dismemberment, Alfredson combines the tenderness of Martin Weiszs psychological horror film Grimm Love (2006) and the vulnerability of Guillermo del Toros dark child fantasy Pans Labyrinth (2006). Our personal favourite? The swimming pool scene at the end of the film. If you think youve seen one too many coming-of-age films or emo vampire romances, allow Alfredson and co to take you to a new terrain of supernatural love.
version.property: NC16 - No children under the age of 16

version.name: The Unborn
version.review: See TOS Reviews.

movie.name: Street Fighter: The Legend of Chun-Li

version.name: Street Fighter: The Legend of Chun-Li
version.review: The 1994 version of this big-screen adaptation of the computer game starring Jean-Claude Van Damme and Kylie Minogue was bad. This years version doesnt show much promise either, but hey, if youre a fan of local actor Edmund Chen and Taboo of Black Eyed Peas, then maybe youd care to watch Chun-Li fight her way to justice.

version.name: Paul Blart: Mall Cop
version.review: Give Kevin James credit hes not afraid to make himself the butt of a lot of fat-guy jokes. Heres what Paul Blart: Mall Cop has to offer: Fat mall security guard gets very hungry, falls down a lot, woos a supposed hottie (Mays) though thanks to the films hideous cinematography, she doesnt look all that hot. Then he foils skateboarding crooks who are into parkour. (How 2007!).

version.name: Hotel for Dogs
version.review: Hotel for Dogs is the story of a couple of orphaned kids who take in stray pups and make a home for them in an abandoned New York hotel. You see, the kids feel a kinship with these castoff mutts because they, too, have no one to look after them. Big-hearted social worker Bernie (Cheadle) is doing his best to find Andi (Roberts) and the precocious Bruce (Austin) a good family, but he really screws the pooch when he lands the siblings with foster parents Lois and Carl Scudder (Lisa Kudrow and Kevin Dillon), a dim-witted couple who intend to form a band and drop their rock manifesto on an unsuspecting world (Drew Toal).

version.name: Frost/Nixon
version.review: See TOS Review.

version.name: Fanboys
version.review: In this overgeeked comedy about twentysomething Star Wars obsessives, the characters engage in crashing Halloween parties in full stormtrooper regalia and live in a universe of video games, comics and Moms garage. When fanboy Linus (Marquette) is revealed to be suffering from terminal cancer, he and his buddies pile into a van and plan to infiltrate George Lucass Bay Area Skywalker Ranch for an illegal peek.

version.name: Dragonball Evolution
version.review: From the same guy who brought you an overdose of Jet Li in The One and the nauseatingly bad third serving of Final Destination comes the big-screen adaptation of Akira Toriyamas manga-turned-TV seriesturned- arcade game.

version.name: Detroit Metal City
version.review: In this film adaptation of the hit Japanese comic book by Kiminori Wakasugi, Soichi Negishi (Matsuyama) travels to Tokyo in hopes of launching a career singing stylish Swedish twee-pop. A twist of fate and a band called Detroit Metal City recruits him to masquerade as a demon emperor named Johannes Krauser II who plays death metal.

version.name: 12 Rounds
version.review: Instead of trying to take over the world, an untraceable international terrorist cooks up a game called 12 steps to saving your girlfriend while you try to overcome dangerous obstacles. WWE star John Cena plays detective Danny Fisher, the unwilling playmate.

version.name: Watchmen
version.review: The kids at 20th Century Fox and Warner Bros have finally settled their differences; most of us however, are still fighting over who gets to be The Comedian at the next Halloween party. Zack Snyders adaptation of the Alan Moore graphic novel follows Rorschach and his investigation into the mysterious death of fellow Watchmen, The Comedian. With the clock counting down, a sinister force systematically kills the jaded superheroes as their world watches and does nothing. So when a nuclear war threatens the lives of the common man, these costumed vigilantes have to ask themselves whether they care enough to give a sh*t.

version.name: Serbis
version.review: Mostly handheld, always frenetic and always noisy, Serbis dips in and out of the lives of the sprawling members of the Pineda family, who run the cinema and live in it, and their various physical, sexual, legal and financial quandaries. The most impressive aspect of Mendozas seventh film in four years is how it lives and breathes its one location: a rundown sex cinema in Angeles City called Family (we learn the name from the films one exterior shot of the building in which the family sits suggestively next to a sign that reads Mendoza).

version.name: Push
version.review: Chris Evans is pleasant enough to look at, in a fratboy way, but hes not someone youd pick to develop an intricate plan to outsmart his opponents. So its pretty amusing when, in the middle of this rebel-kids-withpsychic- powers-versus-evil-governmentagency mess, telekinetic slacker Evans suddenly demonstrates the strategic gifts of Carl von Clausewitz. But you shouldnt be looking for plausibility in a movie that features psychics getting info by sniffing toothbrushes; you want kick-ass fights and chases. Alas, McGuigans jittery editing and shaky cameras make the action confusing rather than thrilling, and nothing can save this movie from the screenplays nearly incomprehensible twists and turns (Hank Sartin).

version.name: Taken
version.review: Liam Neeson plays Bryan, a retired spy whose daughter, played by Maggie Grace (Lost), is abducted by slave traders on the streets of Paris. Bryan pursues the captors across Europe, using the skills hes learned in the espionage game to track them down and free the girl.
version.property: NC16 - No children under the age of 16

version.name: Suspect X
version.review: A brilliant but eccentric physicist engages in a battle of wits against an intuitive and analytical detective. Based on the award-winning novel series by Keigo Higashino, this Japanese whodunit has already topped box-office charts back home.

version.name: Role Models
version.review: Hauled in by the cops following a rampaging energy-juice bender, Danny (Rudd) and Wheeler (a mercifully restrained Seann William Scott) are sentenced to 150 hours of community service in the company of two troubled kids: hyperactive, foul-mouthed ten-year old Ronnie (Thompson) and role-playing Dungeons & Dragons nerd Augie (Mintz- Plasse).

version.name: The Reader
version.review: Bernhard Schlinks 1995 Holocaust novel-adaptation stars both Ralph Fiennes and David Kross as Michael Berg, a German boy-turned-lawyer, who encounters an older trolleybus worker (Winslet) in the pivotal moments of his life, with both good and bad effect

version.name: The Pink Panther 2
version.review: Steve Martin plays not-sosmooth Inspector Clouseau in the second theatrical release of the 1993s television cult series that has Jean Reno reprising his role, and joined by newcomer Aishwarya Rai.

version.name: Outlander
version.review: James Caviezel plays a visitor from an alien world who crash lands on earth bringing with him a violent monster. The actor was last spotted playing Jesus in Mel Gibsons controversial though highly successful The Passion of the Christ.

movie.name: The Other End of the Line

version.name: The Other End of the Line
version.review: A woman who works at a call centre in India falls in love with one of her callers and travels to San Francisco to meet him.

version.name: New in Town
version.review: Renée Zellweger braves the Minnesota cold in her new comedy and plays Lucy, a highpowered consultant who has to give up her comfortable consultant digs to oversee the restructuring of a manufacturing plant suited for blue-collared workers.

version.name: K-20: Legend of the Mask
version.review: In this action-adventure, hot stuff Takeshi Kaneshiro plays a masked crusader who fights the war against aristocrats, much like Alan Moores revolutionary character V.

version.name: Underworld: Rise of the Lycans
version.review: In the prequel to 2003s horror-action flick Underworld, Bill Nighy reprises his rightful role as Viktor, the powerful but delusional vampire leader.

version.name: Slumdog Millionaire
version.review: Read our Review.

version.name: Gran Torino
version.review: In the actors latest directorial feature, Clint Eastwood (Changeling, Letters from Iwo Jima) tells the story of a Korean War veteran who develops an unlikely friendship with a young Hmong teenager.

version.name: Forever Enthralled
version.review: In this biopic, Leon Lai plays the enigmatic Mei Lanfang who was one of Chinas most sought-after opera singers. The performer, who only seeks to lead a life of normality, enthrals both men and women, leaving a trail of broken hearts wherever he performs.

movie.name: The Curious Case of Benjamin Button

version.name: The Curious Case of Benjamin Button
version.review: Dir: David Fincher

version.name: Rachel Getting Married
version.review: Dir: Jonathan Demme

version.name: Elegy
version.review: Isabel Coixet

version.name: Traitor
version.review: Cheadle is an American arms dealer imprisoned in Yemen who rediscovers his Muslim roots and joins the jihad, only to find himself shipped to train suicide attackers in the US. The first half is dark and compelling, drawing us into the world of the terrorist and displaying a courageous ethical and narrative complexity (Tom Huddleston).
version.property: M18 - No one under the age of 18 admitted

version.name: Seven Pounds
version.review: The choice of Fresh Prince Will Smith to take on the role of Oldboy, the comic, has created a real stir. Before deciding whether you love or hate the adaptation, watch as Smith portrays a suicidal IRS agent who decides to help seven individuals before he calls it quits.

version.name: Morning Light
version.review: A group of 15 young men and women takes to the open seas as they embark on a sailing competition against top professionals. Feel the determination and watch as these sailors bond over their love for the water.

version.name: The Haunting of Molly Hartley
version.review: Vintage satanic-conspiracy clichés abound in this tame thriller packed with TV actors. Molly (Bennett) and her father want a fresh start after her crazy mother tries to kill her. They move to a new town, but Molly packs plenty of baggage: nightmares, nosebleeds, aural hallucinations etc. She compounds her problems by befriending the class outcast (Collins) and crossing the alpha mean girl (McCord) by flirting with her dreamboat boyfriend (Crawford). If you know your devil-cult movies, you wont be surprised how this one turns out (Maitland McDonagh).

version.name: The Duchess
version.review: Knightley seems to have fallen into the habit of appearing in costume drama. In her latest period film, she stars as the Duchess of Devonshire, married to a boring duke (Fiennes) and in pursuit of her teenage crush, Charles Grey (Cooper).
version.property: M18 - No one under the age of 18 admitted

version.name: Doubt
version.review: Based on his own Pulitzer Prize-winning play, Shanley directs Academy Award winners Hoffman as charismatic priest Father Flynn, and Streep as the unwavering principal, Sister Aloysius. When Father Flynn is accused of befriending a student, the proverbial excrement hits the fan when Father and Sister engage in a battle of wills.

version.name: Chandni Chowk to China
version.review: From Delhi to Shanghai, this is Bollywoods first kung fu comedy. Kumar plays a good-for-nothing food-stall vendor whose life changes when two strangers bring him news that he was a war hero in a previous life.

version.name: Bride Wars
version.review: Hell hath no fury like a bride scorned. Take pleasure out of watching Hathaway (whos turning into a wedding-movie specialist) and Hudson play two brides-to-be fighting over the same date: who will win this race down the aisle?

version.name: Yes Man
version.review: Don't expect anything different than Carrey's usual over-the-top brand of humour in his latest slapstick. In Yes Man, Carrey plays Carl Allen, a loser who signs up for a self-help program only to realise that a 'yes attitude' may not always end in a lifetime of success.

version.name: Twilight
version.review: In this years fantasy showdown, the eternally seventeen vampires of author Stephenie Meyers young adult fiction takes on Harry Potter. With incredibly styled hair, pasty skin and a lot of brooding, will this modern-day love story between a mortal and a vampire rise above the hocos pocus and very focused magicians at Hogwarts?

version.name: The Spirit
version.review: Before you dismiss the been-there-done-Sin City aesthetic, The Spirit was one of Will Eisners most influential works, and has inspired comic artists since the 40s. Adapted for the screen by Miller, check out newcomer Macht in the title role and Jackson as the villainous Octopus but the real treats are femmes fatales ScarJo, Mendes, Vega and King.

movie.name: The Day the Earth Stood Still

version.name: The Day the Earth Stood Still
version.review: Reeves plays the alien who visits Earth in this 2008 remake of the 1951 classic. As scientist and government suits scramble to figure out the reason for his arrival, a mother (Connelly) and son (Smith) get caught up in the unearthly mess.

version.name: Bolt
version.review: Faster than a speeding bullet, its not a bird, its not a plane its a super-dog. Bolt (voiced by Travolta) thinks his powers are real, and when this star of a hit TV show is separated from his owner, Penny (voiced by Essman), he begins his off-screen adventure with the help of a jaded housecat and a TV-junkie hamster named Rhino.

version.name: Bedtime Stories
version.review: In this tall tale, Sandler plays a hotel handyman named Skeeter Bronson with the gift of the gab. When the stories Bronson tells his niece and nephew start coming to life, he takes advantage of the situation and spins one outlandish tale after the other. Its only when the kids get in on the action that he realises some things are better left unsaid.

version.name: Australia
version.review: Set prior to World War II, Australia centres on an English aristocrat, Lady Sarah Ashley (Kidman), who finds herself unexpectedly fighting to save a cattle station the size of Belgium. When local cattle barons plot to take her land, she reluctantly joins forces with a rough-hewn cattle drover (Jackman) to drive 1,500 head of cattle across northern Australias breathtaking landscape. Love ensues, but they must still face the bombing of Darwin by the Japanese forces that had attacked Pearl Harbor only months earlier.

version.name: Cape No. 7
version.review: A failed rock star (Aga) returns to his small hometown to work as a mailman. When an audition for a warm-up band for a successful local musicians concert opens up, Aga decides to give it a shot with the help of a crew of musically inclined misfits.

movie.name: Winx Club: The Secret of the Lost Kingdom

version.name: Winx Club: The Secret of the Lost Kingdom
version.review: This Italian animated TV series has finally made it to the big screen. While in search for her parents, Bloom (Ciampa) begins her journey to uncover the secret of the lost kingdom Domino. Things get messy when evil forces escape the dark realm called the Circle of Obsidian, interrupting the family reunion.

version.name: Saw V
version.review: The latest installment of the now-annual Saw franchise with Tobin Bell returning as the demented serial killer, Jigsaw.
version.property: R21 - No one under the age of 21 admitted

version.name: The Coffin
version.review: In this highest-grossing horror movie in Thailand, director Uekrongtham (Beautiful Boxer) turns the ancient Thai ritual of lying in coffins to banish bad luck into a scream gem. Chris, a claustrophobic architect, goes in the box in the hope of saving his fiancée, who is dying of cancer. The lovebirds get married but like most (supposed) happy endings, things go wrong in bizarre and terrifying ways.

version.name: Wild Child
version.review: 'Thats the final straw, you are going to England! belts out Malibu dad Quinn as he sends his brat daughter (Roberts) across the Atlantic for yet another film set in a British boarding school. Roberts rollercoaster accent of rising vowels and spoiled be-yatch attitude dont go down well among the jolly-hockeysticks crowd, but those girls, led by uppity head Georgia King, arent so palatable either.

version.name: Transporter 3
version.review: Co-written by Luc Besson (The Fifth Element, Taxi), life-sized toy soldier Statham springs into action yet again as Frank Martin in this third instalment of the entertaining no-brainer series.

version.name: The Sky Crawlers
version.review: The renowned Ghost in the Shell director is back with something a little more mainstream, yet still distinctively Oshii. Adapted from Mori Hiroshis bestselling Japanese novel, The Sky Crawlers is set in an imaginary world where perennial adolescents called Kildren fight every single day for consumption by the media and public.

version.name: Sing to the Dawn
version.review: Filmed on the island of Batam, this animated tale is adapted from Minfong Hoâs 1975 short story about Dawan, a young girl desperate to escape her village to pursue a scholarship in the city. Against her fatherâs wishes, Dawan sets out to prove to herself and the villagers that sheâs more than capable of handling the big wide world. In cinemas now.

version.name: Quarantine
version.review: Once again, gory horrors befall oddly committed videographers in this case, a TV crew trapped inside a rabies-infected Los Angeles building swarming with flesh-chompers.

version.name: Quantum of Solace
version.review: The ailing James Bond series was well and truly rebooted with 2006s hard-as-nails Casino Royale, and Quantum of Solace the latest addition to that failsafe franchise sets to carry on in that general direction. Daniel Craig slinks into the role of the suave secret agent with aplomb, but instils the unflappable ladies man with much-needed angst and moral apprehension. Brit lass Gemma Arterton, whos had recent starring roles in St Trinians and Three and Out, crops up as the Bond girl; the plot reportedly follows Bonds clashes with an environmentalist who aims to steal a countrys entire water supply. Read an interview with Director Marc Forster.

version.name: Madagascar: Escape 2 Africa
version.review: Like the adventure reality show Survivor but with talking animals, the sequel to Madagascar sees your favourite zoo residents out in the wildthis time, in Africa.

version.name: Lakeview Terrace
version.review: A yuppie couple (Wilson and Washington) moves to a diverse block next door to a widowed, vaguely militant police officer (Jackson), who claims to be out to protect the neighbourhood. However, he also seems a little hostile toward his neighbours interracial marriage.

version.name: Four Christmases
version.review: Witherspoon and Vaughn produce and star in a film about excess holiday baggage having to visit all four of their divorced parents on Christmas Day.

version.name: The Women
version.review: Diane Englishs abysmal remake of George

version.name: Choke
version.review: Dir Clark Gregg

version.name: Body of Lies
version.review: Leonardo DiCaprio plays a super capable CIA agent setting up shop in Jordan. He speaks the terse language of operational tactics hes after a bin Laden-like spectre and flirts with a sly nurse (Farahani) in fluent Arabic. DiCaprio has never been afraid to come off like a hothead, and when his plans go awry, he lights up the movie with rage.

version.name: Max Payne
version.review: In this adaptation of a thirdperson shooting game, Payne (Wahlberg) is an ex-police officer bent on avenging the death of his wife and child. A drug known as Valkyr has been leaked onto the streets originally designed to make super-soldiers for the military, its a hallucinogen that makes crack look like chocolate. As Payne sniffs out the conspiracy behind the trafficking, hes led to the one who might have prescribed the death of his family.

version.name: Marigold
version.review: Stranded in Goa when funding for her latest flick falls through, American actress Marigold (Larter) accepts a dancing role in a Bollywood musical and enlists the help of Prem (Khan), a choreographer, to teach her some moves.

version.name: The Oxford Murders
version.review: As the title suggests, this is a good ol-fashioned crime thriller. Wood plays a postgraduate student investigating a string of murders linked by a series of mathematical symbols, aided by a logic professor played by screen veteran Hurt.
version.property: M18 - No one under the age of 18 admitted

version.name: Burn After Reading
version.review: The Coens return to a lighter, glossier vein after their Oscar-winning No Country for Old Men with this dramedy about a missing CIA memoir.

version.name: Brideshead Revisited
version.review: The big-screen adaptation of Evelyn Waughs 1945 novel about a family of aristocratic Catholics sees Whishaw as Sebastian, Atwell as his suffering sister, and Goode as the outsider who falls under the siblings spell. Much of the film was shot in Castle Howard in northern England, chief location of the celebrated 1981 television adaptation.

version.name: Blindness
version.review: Blindness is a slick and murky adaptation of Portuguese writer José Saramagos allegorical novel about a city thats devastated by a plague of blindness. One by one, the citizens of an anonymous metropolis lose their sight until the government sees fit to quarantine a frightened group of victims in a disused mental hospital.

version.name: American Teen
version.review: American Teen is, ostensibly, a documentary. That it works so well as a melodrama, better even than The Breakfast Club, raises vexing issues (if you let it).

version.name: My Magic
version.review: Khoo's latest movie...
version.property: NC16 - No children under the age of 16

version.name: Tropic Thunder
version.review: Let us now praise Robert Downey...

version.name: RocknRolla
version.review: Wrong-footed by the new credit crunch...

version.name: Eagle Eye
version.review: From the same team that brought you Disturbia, Carusos second date with LaBeouf (all grown-up and with a goatee) ends up in an entangled web of murder and deceit. Monaghan and the pubescent play a mother-and-son team who are unwillingly drawn into an elaborate plan to assassinate a member of the White House.

version.name: Connected
version.review: East meets West and vice versa, this film by Hong Kongs Benny Chan (Rob-B-Hood, Divergence) is a remake of the Hollywood version Cellular starring Kim Basinger. The storys the same; a guy receives a phone call from a distressed lady claiming shes been kidnapped. It becomes a race-against-time for the youngun as he outwits, outplays and outlasts the perpetrators.

version.name: The Midnight Meat Train
version.review: Based on Clive Barkers short story of the same title and starring Brooke Shields and Vinnie Jones (Snatch, Gone in Sixty Seconds), Japanese director Ryuhei Kitamura (Azumi, Sky High) takes it frame by frame as we follow a New York Photographer on the hunt of a gruesome serial killer.

version.name: My Sassy Girl
version.review: If the Korean version of this sweet-toothed dramadey wasnt good enough then feast on American cuties Jesse Bradford and Elisha Cuthbert as they play the game of love in English. Bradford plays a sweet guy who gets f**ked over by complicated and elusive Cuthbert.

version.name: Bangkok Dangerous
version.review: A remake of the Pang Brothers 1999 film of the same name, this version sees Hollywood grizzly Nicolas Cage play an assassin with a conscious named Joe. While seeing to a series of contracts, Cage befriends a local urchin, Kong (Shahkrit Yamnarm) who becomes his errand boy. Joe takes Kong under his wing while the young apprentice starts to question his masters trade. The film escalates in a showdown where Joe has to decide whether hed rather save Kong or leave the country unharmed.

version.name: Step Brothers
version.review: You last saw this pair in Talladega Nights: The Ballad of Ricky Bobby, and now theyre back to encourage senseless, uninhibited laughter. Ferrell and Reilly play 39-year-olds who still live with their single parents. When their respective folks decide to get married, the man-boys are forced to live together. What ensues is an unhinged repertoire between both comic actors as they fart, burp, laugh and cry their way into your hearts.

version.name: The Rocker
version.review: From the same director who brought you The Full Monty comes this comedic satire about an ageing drummer who is asked to leave his 80s throwback band Vesuvius. Passionate and dedicated to living the rock-star life, he joins his nephews high-school band A.D.D., much to their initial disapproval. But they soon realise this relic is too cool for school, and the boys get a hint of sex, and not so much drugs, but definitely a lot of rock n roll.

version.name: Mirrors
version.review: In this supernatural thriller Sutherland plays Ben Carson, who moves into a house with his lovely wife and child, unaware that an evil force is trying to enter their realm through mirrors.
version.property: M18 - No one under the age of 18 admitted

version.name: The House Bunny
version.review: Shes pink and fluffy and, you guessed it, a Playboy bunny. Unfortunately Shelly (Faris) gets tossed out of the mansion and onto the streets. She stumbles upon a sorority of girls who require a much-needed fluffing up. Think Legally Blonde with the same subversive message of rising above ones expectations, with added bunny ears.

version.name: The Banishment
version.review: A straying Alex (Lavronenko) moves his wife and kids back to the countryside where he was born. However, instead of improving his frayed relationship with his wife (Bonnevie), son (Shibayev) and daughter (Kulkina), the desolate countryside offers no solace and only serves to encapsulate the loneliness and detachment the family suffers. A beautiful but heart-wrenching film.

version.name: Babylon A.D.
version.review: If the movie doesnt have a hot babe, a fast car, an end-of-the-world scenario, the government or some ass kickin involved, Vin Diesel would probably not be in it. In Babylon A.D., theres a hot babe (Thierry) carrying an organism inside her that has the potential to bring about the second coming of Christ. Set in a post-apocalyptic era, Diesel plays Toorop, a mercenary-turned-reluctant hero who has to decide whether he gives enough of a damn to make a difference.

version.name: Space Chimps
version.review: Coupling the men-on-a-mission antics of Armageddon with the catch-all sci-fi pastiche of TVs Futurama, Space Chimps is an underwhelming slice of lowbrow CGI entertainment. When a hi-tech space probe veers off course on to an uncharted planet, a team of NASA chimpanzees are assigned to a retrieval mission.

version.name: Star Wars: The Clone Wars
version.review: George Lucas begins his anticipated television series with the theatrical debut of Star Wars in 3-D. In Star Wars: The Clone Wars, youll bear witness to the intergalactic struggle between good and evil in eye-popping, state-of-the-art, computer-generated animation (that was a mouthful). Your favourite characters like Count Dooku, Anakin Skywalker, C-3PO, Yoda, Obi-Wan Kenobi will all make an appearance albeit digitalised.

version.name: Meet Dave
version.review: Its the brotherhood from another planet in Meet Dave, a silly family comedy in which the intrepid Captain (Murphy) leads a pint-size team from the planet Nill in a quest to steal salt from Earths oceans. Their intergalactic spaceship takes the form of a humanoid craft called Dave. Attempting a more succinct explanation of the harebrained, dime-store sci-fi plot is futile at no point does the story make any sense. Watching Murphy robotically walk around the city does stir nostalgia for the brilliant Saturday Night Live skit in which he masqueraded as an uptight white guy, but that formidable comic actor is long gone. (Drew Toal)

version.name: Forgetting Sarah Marshall
version.review: Read our review here.

version.name: Death Race
