version.review: Statham (Lock, Stock and Two Smoking Barrels) stars in the remake of Roger Cormans cult classic Death Race 2000. The original starred Sylvester Stallone and David Carradine. The rules were simple back then: the more fellow drivers or innocent bystanders you run down, the more points you get tongue-in-cheek and violent. Anderson (Resident Evil and Alien vs Predator) might not have the same sense of humour, but he does have a knack for hardcore action. Strap on

version.name: 12 Lotus
version.review:
Following up his kitschy hit musical 881 about Hungry Ghost Festivals getai concerts, local director Royston Tans back with 12 Lotus. The plot follows a female singer who has a seriously long run of abusive manfriends from the 1980s till the present day. Lets hope 12 Lotus will bring Tan the same success that 881 did.
In Mandarin with English subtitles.

movie.name: Journey to the Center of the Earth

version.name: Journey to the Center of the Earth
version.review: In 1975, Rick Wakemans irrefutable dexterity on the electronic keyboard was the pretext for bringing Jules Vernes wide-eyed 1864 adventure novel to a new audience. Now, with the aid of man-mannequin Brendan Fraser, this rousing, inquisitive tale of three explorers heading into the bowels of the Earth has been unfortunately beleaguered with more pointless gimmickry this time the migraine-inducing sideshow of 3-D. (David Jenkins)

version.name: The Love Guru
version.review: An oh-my-God-level disaster thatll make you wonder if Hollywood actually hates movie-goers, The Love Guru tempts our zero-stars rating and not just for the cringeworthy vamping of its out-of-touch star, Mike Myers, playing Pitka, his purring, creeptastic faux healer (more appropriate for a Saturday Night Live skit circa 1976). (Joshua Rothkopf)
version.property: NC16 - No children under the age of 16

version.name: Summer Rain
version.review: Banderas returned to his 1970s Málaga roots for this second stint behind the camera (after 1999s Crazy in Alabama), about a group of friends searching for a purpose in an era of limited opportunity. Adapted by Antonio Soler from his own novel, it centres on Miguelito (Alberto Amarilla) who has just recovered from a kidney operation and dreams of becoming a poet and the girl he falls for, aspiring dancer Luli (Ruiz).
version.property: R21 - No one under the age of 21 admitted

version.name: Sparrow
version.review: A gang of pickpockets led by Kei (Yam) is called upon by a mysterious femme fatale named Chun Lei (Lin) to steal a key for her. Little does he know, shes been spying on him, perched on a windowsill, across the room from where he lives.

version.name: Shaolin Girl
version.review:
First there was Shaolin Soccer (2001), so why not let the girls play ball this time? In Japans answer to the Hong Kong hit, Rin (Shibasaki) is a martial arts expert who packs a punch. After spending years in the temple training with monks, Rin decides to return to Hong Kong when her grandfathers martial arts school faces TKO.
In Japanese, Mandarin and Cantonese with English subtitles.

version.name: Red Cliff
version.review: In this highly anticipated historical epic, Woo heads home and back in time. Its 208AD, and 100,000 peasants flee with leader Liu Bei from Cao Caos (Zhang) army with the aid of warriors like Zhao Yun (Leung) and strategist Zhuge Liang (Kaneshiro). They escape across the Yangtze to take refuge with Sun Quan, the leader of the south. Meanwhile, Cao Cao prepares an army to search and destroy.

movie.name: The Mummy: Tomb of the Dragon Emperor

version.name: The Mummy: Tomb of the Dragon Emperor
version.review: Brendan Frasers second special-effects extravaganza this summer returns him to his well-known role as tomb-raiding adventurer Rick OConnell. This Far East ghost story sends OConnell and his son (newcomer Luke Ford) into the Chinese Himalayas for encounters with an emperor whos been released from a 2,000-year-old curse, a sneaky sorceress, armies of the resurrected and even a hydra. (Stephen Garrett)

version.name: Meet Bill
version.review: Bills (Eckhart) beautiful wife Jess (Banks) starts an affair with a handsome news reporter (Olyphant). Bill then pretends to date a lingerie saleswoman played by one of FHM magazines bombshells, Jessica Alba, to make his wife jealous.

version.name: Children of Glory
version.review: The water polo final at the 1956 Melbourne Olympics remains one of the most acrimonious encounters in sporting history, an aquatic battle pitting the Hungarian team against the Soviet Union as the Red Army was crushing the political uprising in Budapest.

version.name: The Bank Job
version.review: Brit thesp Saffron Burrows and action man du jour Jason Statham star in this comic heist movie that documents the 1971 robbery of a bank on Londons Baker Street. Despite landing a haul of £3 million (S$9m) in cash and jewels, no arrests were made and no money retrieved; the robbery was rumoured to have been connected to a royal sex scandal that the government was trying to keep hush-hush.

version.name: Art of the Devil 3
version.review:
If youre into gore, and lots of it, then let sexy Panor (an excellent Nakprasit) open the floodgates as a schoolteacher who has to kill a shaman, with voodoo-obsessed Sergeant Dit (Kitsuwan) as her accomplice. We strongly recommend this as the perfect date movie.
In Thai with English subtitles.

version.name: 10 Promises to My Dog
version.review: A cute golden retriever puppy wanders into the life of a 14-year-old schoolgirl, Akari (Tanaka), living in Hokkaido, Japan. Her mum agrees to keep Socks, but only if Akari promises to give the dog ten wishes and fulfils them. The pair (dog and girl) form a bond as they face lifes challenges together, such as getting used to peeing in one spot and dealing with heartbreak.

version.name: Hancock
version.review: Alas, this is not a biopic of one of Britains best-loved comedy curmudgeons, but an action comedy starring Will Smith as a Superman-like hero who, due to a series of high-profile (and alcohol-fuelled) blunders, has fallen out of favour with the public.

version.name: Wanted
version.review: Based on the graphic novel series by Mark Millar, and helmed by the director who gave you Night and Day Watch, comes this explosive thriller where Average Joe Wes (McAvoy) gets picked up by Fox (Jolie), a sexy woman with just-as-sexy guns. Wes is introduced to a fraternity led by Sloan (Freeman), a secret society of agents with phenomenal agility. Kick-ass action, stunning visual effects and star power make this film the perfect weapon.

version.name: Strange Wilderness
version.review: This stoner comedy from Happy Madison Productions follows the goofy misadventures of wildlifetelevision host Peter (Zahn) and his band of bong-ripping nature enthusiasts (including Adam Sandler mainstays Covert and Peter Dante) as they follow the trail of Bigfoot in South America. (Drew Toal)

version.name: The Strangers
version.review:
Not based on a true story, but inspired by similar events, this film tells the terrifying tale of the Hoyt family (not their real surname) while vacationing in their home (rumoured to be in Arkansas) on February 2005. What starts as a joyous occasion for couple Kristen McKay (Tyler) and James Hoyt (Speedman) gets ugly when a knock on the door at 4am introduces a masked stranger with macabre intentions.
Read full review.

version.name: Shine a Light
version.review: See review.

version.name: The Ruins
version.review: Ultimately, a doozy of a leap has to be made with The Ruins both Scott Smiths best-selling horror novel and this mostly faithful, far-from trashy adaptation. What are we leaping to? Flesh-eating, sentient, murderousvines. Yup: evil plants. They swirl atop an ancient Mexican pyramid tower, upon which four curious American vacationers and a disabled German find themselves forcibly quarantined by the locals. (Joshua Rothkopf)
version.property: M18 - No one under the age of 18 admitted

version.name: Never Back Down
version.review: The eternal battle between the hot-but-arrogant blonde and the hot-and-likeable brunette continues on new turf in the almost gleefully bad Never Back Down. This time, the contenders are shirtless guys and the field of play is mixed martial arts. When Jake (Faris, looking eerily like the young Tom Cruise), a teen with rage issues, moves from the Corn Belt to an Orlando high school where the cool kids are into underground fighting, hes like fresh meat in a sun-drenched prison. Hes immediately scoped out by rich-kid a**hole Ryan (Gigandet, distilled essence of handsome pr**k), who wants to beat Jake to a pulp. (Hank Sartin)

movie.name: In the Name of the King

version.name: In the Name of the King
version.review: See review.

version.name: The Incredible Hulk
version.review: Deemed too clever by moviegoers in 2003, Ang Lees amiable, intellectual reading of Marvel Comics angry, green action hero, The Incredible Hulk didnt really muscle in on the box-office paydirt that is generally expected of gaudy comic-book adaptations. How to remedy that? Make another film on exactly the same subject with a different director and leading man. Ed Norton stars as the anger-prone scientist Bruce Banner and its directed by Louis Leterrier, the man who gave us the action-packed Transporter films.

version.name: The Happening
version.review: Theres a certain haunting quality to Shyamalans films, and like The Sixth Sense, Signs and The Village, there is a lot left to the imagination even after youve seen The Happenings trailer. In this new film, the world faces an unknown threat, which isnt terrorism (for once).

version.name: Get Smart
version.review: Big-screen version of the hit 1960s comedy about an accident-prone spy called Maxwell Smart. The film version sees Smart (Carell), who works for the secretive government agency CONTROL, battling the dastardly KAOS with the help of Agent 99 (Hathaway) and the newly created character Agent 23 (Johnson).

version.name: Bad Habits
version.review: We are all creatures of habit, but when it turns into something uncontrollable, it becomes a disorder. There is no easy way to tackle the issue of anorexia, which is this films focus. Three women represent different facets of obsession an emaciated mother, her chubby daughter and her husbands buxom female student with a hearty appetite (and not for food).
version.property: M18 - No one under the age of 18 admitted

movie.name: All the Boys Love Mandy Lane

version.name: All the Boys Love Mandy Lane
version.review: Mandy Lane. Beautiful. Untouched. Highschool royalty waiting to be crowned. Since the dawn of junior year, men have tried to make her theirs. Some have even died in reckless pursuit of this 16-year-old Texas angel. Chloe (Able) and Red (Himelstein) invite Mandy out to Reds family ranch for the weekend. Mandy (Heard) sees it as an excellent opportunity to cement her new friendships. The boys see it as an opportunity to finally get time alone with her. Driving across Texas, the kids begin to gently chip away at the wall that surrounds her. However, as night falls and the booze, drugs and hormones take over, things are said and advances made that can never be reversed.

Based on a true story about a bunch of MIT students who learn to count cards and win big in Las Vegas. Their winnings are enough to pay for their entire education, but soon one of them gets too greedy and things get out of hand.
Read our review of 21.

version.name: Kung Fu Panda
version.review: Po the Panda works as a waiter in an Asian restaurant. And like most waiters who work in Asian restaurants, they secretly aspire to be kung fu experts (okay, thats a generalisation). The hilarious Jack Black lends his voice to the lazy-by-nature mammal who happens to be The One. With powerful enemies lurking, Po has to fulfil his prophecy and save the world, under the leadership of his guru, Master Shifu (Hoffman).

movie.name: Indiana Jones and the Kingdom of the Crystal Skull

version.name: Indiana Jones and the Kingdom of the Crystal Skull
version.review: See Keeping up with the Joneses.

version.name: Wilde
version.review: If anybody was born to play Oscar Wilde, it must have been Stephen Fry: not only does he look like the playwright, but he himself is often portrayed as being too clever and too complex for his own good. Gilberts film, with an intelligent screenplay by Julian Mitchell based on Richard Ellmanns biography, looks curiously old-fashioned. More lavish than Merchant Ivory, its a 60sstyle Technicolor affair with a grown-up 90s feel. Unlike its predecessors, its able to be frank about the sexual encounters: with devoted friend Robbie Ross; with rent boys to whom Wilde was indulgently generous; and, fatefully, with the love of his life, the beautiful, wilful, spoilt brat Lord Alfred (Bosie) Douglas, who didnt fancy Wilde, but saw him as the alternative to his brutal, bullying father, the Marquess of Queensberry. As Wilde, descending from would-be-doting husband and father to follower of his own nature, and finally ruined and disgraced martyr on the tree of English hypocrisy, Fry is utterly convincing.

version.name: What Happens in Vegas
version.review: Britney Spears and a childhood friend get married in Vegaswait, someone pass me the film synopsis. Two strangers wake up to discover that theyre husband and wife, with a truckload of money from hitting the jackpot the night before. What ensues is undermining, backstabbing and, of course, the perfect ending.

version.name: Taxidermia
version.review: Based on Lajos Parti Nagys short stories, Taxidermia doesnt lend itself to a simple summary. Its twisted plot involves three generation-spanning tales: a grandfather who yearns for love, a father who seeks to master the art of speed-eating and a son, a taxidermist, who works hard at reproducing the perfect human torso by stuffing his own.
version.property: R21 - No one under the age of 21 admitted

version.name: Superhero Movie
version.review: The problem with Epic Movie and Meet the Spartans (if you dont count the sexism, homophobia and lack of funny jokes) is that they try to make fun of everything. Mazin does a far better job of staying focused. Aside from a Tom Cruise YouTube gag, Mazin aims almost exclusively for making fun of Spider-Man and, to a lesser extent, Batman, X-Men and Fantastic Four.

version.name: Speed Racer
version.review: The brothers first since the Matrix films adapts a Japanese cartoon series from the 1960s about a young race car driver. For those of you who arent fans of the cartoon let us give you the gist for this trippy ride. Speed Racer (Hirsch) was born to speed, and in order to save his family racing business, he has to race his one-time rival, the elusive Racer X (Fox).

version.name: Doomsday
version.review: Neil Marshalls mash note to 80s post-apocalyptic action adventure re-creates the eras trashy pleasures with such scrupulous fidelity and distinct lack of irony that youd swear the movie was unearthed from the ruins of a Times Square grindhouse. Despite the Snake Plissken-esque heroine (Mitra), the vibe is more Corman than Carpenter, with Marshall treating the New World Pictures aesthetic topless henchwomen! gonzo explosions! gore in excelsis! as gospel. Its a blatant slab of Britsploitation aimed at lad-mag subscribers; that a specific generation of American genre addicts will be giddy over this is undeniable (David Fear).

version.name: Deception
version.review: People who lead completely boring lives always cross paths with someone whos either an alien, a CIA operative or a gatekeeper to another dimension. In this thriller, McGregor meets Wyatt (Jackman), a lawyer who doesnt always play by the rules.

version.name: Dance of the Dragon
version.review: Starring one of Singapores media darlings, Wong plays Emi Lim, a former ballroom dancing champion forced to leave the spotlight due to an injury. When Tae (Jang), a country boy leaves his hometown in Korea to pursue his passion, he begins dance lessons with Emi. As Taes dancing ability starts to grow, so does his love for Emi.

movie.name: The Chronicles of Narnia: Prince Caspian

version.name: The Chronicles of Narnia: Prince Caspian
version.review: The Narnia boys return in this sequel to the adaptation of The Lion, the Witch and the Wardrobe, to find that the evil King Miraz has usurped their kingdom from its rightful ruler, Prince Caspian. With the help of a mighty mouse named Reepicheep, they set to overthrow the king.

version.name: Drillbit Taylor
version.review: See review.

version.name: Made of Honor
version.review: McDreamy from Greys Anatomy (Dempsey) is just as hot with the ladies on TV as he is on the big screen. In yet another wedding-related comedy-drama, Dempsey loses his best friend (read: love of his life) to a wealthy and handsome Scotsman, and plans to do more than just be maid of honour at their wedding.

version.name: Sex and the City
version.review:
Based on the cult HBO series which was banned in Singapore, the girls are back and reprise their roles as the weekly columnist for The New York Star (Carrie Bradshaw), the conservative and wealthy art dealer (Charlotte York), the career-minded and very cynical lawyer (Miranda Hobbes), and the independent publicist and temptress (Samantha). Look out for Jennifer Hudson of Dreamgirls who will play Carries assistant.
See our review.

version.name: Wedding Daze
version.review: Since American Pie, Jason Biggs has been the star of choice for many a casting agent in search of a hapless hero for a US teen comedy. While aimed at a slightly older audience, Wedding Daze sees him playing to type, opening with a scene in which his character Anderson literally kills his girlfriend through the shock of a marriage proposal. Fast-forward a year, and Andersons friend dares him to start dating again so he proposes to waitress Katie (Fisher). For various reasons, she says yes. Its the first in a series of unlikely events that hold no particular interest in themselves, but do give rise to some amusing scenes, mostly riffing on the Meet the Parents genre; while Andersons parents are suburban swingers on the quiet, Katies stepfather makes Jewish educational toys while her neurotic mother secretly pines for her imprisoned father (Pantoliano). Only about half of the jokes work those that dont often prove painful but the good ones are sharp, dark and sudden enough to draw out laughs of pleasant surprise. A fitfully enjoyable mess. (Anna Smith)
version.property: NC16 - No children under the age of 16

version.name: Street Kings
version.review: The title of this movie was originally The Night Watchman, but was changed to avoid movie-goers from confusing it with Zack Snyders Watchmen. After the boo-hoo-hoo remake of Korean tear-jerker The Lake House (2006), Reeves is back to play Tom Ludlow, a veteran LAPD cop who loses his grip on life after the death of his wife. When evidence surfaces that implicates him in the execution of a fellow officer, Ludlow teams up with a0 young detective (hunky Evans) to clear his name and keep him out of the clutches of the menacing Captain Biggs (Laurie) of Internal Affairs.

version.name: Shutter
version.review: This remake of the Thai chiller of the same name proves that Hollywood has run out of ideas when it comes to scaring us silly. So they turn to the Japanese, Koreans and (now) Thais for spinetingling terror.

version.name: Prom Night
version.review: In this remake of the 1980s horror film starring Jamie Lee Curtis and directed by Paul Lynch, Snow sheds the fat suit she wore in Hairspray to play Donna, a senior in high school all prepped for the (supposed) best night of her life. But the dance takes a deadly turn when a sadistic killer from Donnas past decides to make it a night to remembera night to die for.

version.name: Over Her Dead Body
version.review: See review.

version.name: Iron Man
version.review:
Downey Jr is probably one of the industrys most versatile actors; few in his position would go from playing a drug-induced, alcoholic crime reporter (in last years mammoth thriller Zodiac) to the beefed-up, titular tycoon-cum-superhero in this years Marvel comic big-screen adaptation of Iron Man.
See our review here.

version.name: If I Were Superman
version.review: Leave it to the Koreans to turn a chiselled superhero like Superman into a boy who claims hes unable to tap into his supernatural powers because the bad guys have placed kryptonite inside his head. Despite this, he is intent on helping others, from preventing global warming to rescuing a lost puppy. Soo-jung (Ji-hyun), a producer, is saved by Superman (Jung-min) during an attempted armed robbery. She decides to make a documentary about him and calls it Superman Saves the World. Its a hit however, the real story is that Superman has a bullet lodged in his brain. This realisation makes an ambitious Soo-jung realise whats truly important in life Erm. In Korean with English subtitles.

version.name: Funny Games
version.review: See 'Copycat crimes'

version.name: The Forbidden Kingdom
version.review: Its big adventure in little Chinatown when an American adolescent obsessed with Hong Kong cinema stumbles upon a weapon of the legendary Monkey King. Another one for the books: this is the first time youll get to see superstars Jackie Chan and Jet Li combine forces to deliver a kick-ass martialarts hullabaloo. With the lost relic, the teenager finds himself transported back to ancient China and joining a crew of warriors attempting to free the cheeky Monkey King. Yuen Woo-ping, action choreographer for big-hitters like The Matrix and Crouching Tiger Hidden Dragon, adds a punch to this surefire winner.

version.name: Flood
version.review: Yes, another disaster flick about the end of the world. Cause: global warming. Result: a massive flood that engulfs the whole of London, leaving the city in ruins. Solution: top marine engineers and barrier experts Rob (Carlyle) and ex-wife Sam (Gilsig). Dramatic effect: they only have a few hours to save the city from total devastation.

version.name: Feet Unbound
version.review:
Ng grew up in Singapore and had a job in advertising as a copywriter and creative director. In 2001, he decided to produce a documentary film about the Long March in mid-1930s China. Feet Unbound was filmed on location in China between February and October 2005. The film tells of the courage and hope of Chinas female soldiers in the face of extreme deprivation and brutality.
In Mandarin with English subtitles.

version.name: Definitely, Maybe
version.review: See review.

version.name: Black Book
version.review: See review.
version.property: M18 - No one under the age of 18 admitted

version.name: The Spiderwick Chronicles
version.review: The Spiderwick Chronicles fails to capture the sense of pixie-dusted wonderment that makes Black and DiTerlizzis tomes such page-turners. Other than Highmores impressive doubleduty act, most viewers will find the film indistinguishable from every other kids-inpointy- hats adaptation of the past few years. The voice of the novels is lost in translation; whats left is something thats merely by the book. (David Fear) Photos © Paramount

version.name: Midnight Eagle
version.review: Based on the novel by writer Tetsuo Takashima, director Izuru Narushima sets this action thriller in the northern Alps of Japan. When a photographer (Osawa) witnesses the crash of a US aircraft nicknamed Midnight Eagle, he finds himself in the middle of an international hunt for a secret payload a warhead that threatens to wipe out Japans entire population. In Japanese with English and Mandarin subtitles.

version.name: The Leap Years
version.review: Not as whimsical as Love Me If You Dare (2003) or as intelligent as Before Sunset (2004), Leap Years tells the tale of Li-Ann (Chen), a dreamer and a strong believer in the soulmate theory. Thats until she meets Jeremy, and its love at first sight. The couple spend their honeymoon period touring Chinatown on 29 February 1980. And as all fantasies play out, Li-Ann gets her heart broken when Jeremy confesses that hes married. He decides to make it up to her by meeting her at the same time, same place, every leap year. This affair spans a period of 20 years until they realise that in order to fulfil one anothers desires, they have to take a leap of faith.

version.name: L: Change the World
version.review: In this highly anticipated Death Note (2006) spinoff, L (Matsuyama) is faced with yet another serious case and only has 23 days to solve it. But fate does not lie solely in his hands; a little boy and girl hold the keys to solving the case. As L faces a crisis of global magnitude, he has to protect the kids and find the answers with his days numbered. In Japanese with English and Mandarin subtitles.

version.name: Juno
version.review: Read our review of Juno.

version.name: The Great Debaters
version.review: Read our review of The Great Debaters.

version.name: Evangelion: 1.0 You Are (Not) Alone
version.review: Fans of Japans long-running anime franchise Neon Genesis Evangelion will rejoice at this reworking of that TV classic. All that remains of Japan is Tokyo-3, a city tyrannised by giant creatures that seek to eradicate mankind. Hope comes in the tiny form of a boy named Shinji Ikari, who receives a phone call instructing him to go to the NERV Headquarters an organisation that deals with the destruction of the giants using mechs called Evas. Shinji heads Eva Unit 01 together with Eva Unit 00 pilot, Ayanami Rei. Photos courtesy of The Cathay
version.property: NC16 - No children under the age of 16

version.name: Charlie Bartlett
version.review: Only in America would a school dropout like Charlie Bartlett (Yelchin) make money from being an underground, under-aged shrink. But when he starts falling for one of his patients the bold daughter (Dennings) of the schools disenchanted principal (Downey Jr), Bartlett begins to discover theres a whole lot more to making a difference than handing out antidepressants.

version.name: Brick Lane
version.review: Director Sarah Gavron is thoroughly polite in her adaptation of British writer Monica Alis much-loved novel. So polite that this graceful tale of lives lived day-by-day, millimetre-bymillimetre, comes off as oddly flat-footed and modest in its lack of drama. Opening in Bangladesh in the 80s, Nazneen (Chatterjee) is a thoughtful teenager dispatched to an east London estate to marry a frog-faced man twice her age. Skip to 2001, and Nazneen is a mother of two whose narrow world expands a little when she takes a job stitching up clothes for the rag trade. Soon, shes having an affair with a younger man, Karim (Simpson).
version.property: NC16 - No children under the age of 16

version.name: Becoming Jane
version.review:
So, according to recent research, a youthful spot of ill-fated love helped mould Jane Austen into a great writer, and on the back of that comes this capable biographical drama. Perhaps unexpectedly, Hathaway projects the insightfulness of the future author with no little charm, and McAvoys charismatic enough to convince as the slightly cocky object of her ardour (if less persuasive in bare-torsoed boxing scenes). Overall, the approach is less fluffily contrived than youd expect, and though the alignment of circumstance and social status thwarting innocent passions is hardly fresh, its handled with thoughtful decorum. (Trevor Johnston)
Photos courtesy of The Cathay

version.name: Away from Her
version.review: Read our review on Away from Her.

movie.name: Walk Hard: The Dewey Cox Story

version.name: Walk Hard: The Dewey Cox Story
version.review: Dewey Cox (Reilly) goes through the stations of the pop-music-biopic cross: the judgemental parent, the song inspired by a casual remark, the slide into substance abuse, the creative impasse and the late-career moment of affirmation. Screenwriters Judd Apatow and Kasdan send up every cliché of the genre. Of course, they also include a machete accident played for laughs, a bit of gratuitous full-frontal male nudity and a monkey. The result is an amusing but uneven mesh of clever material (the songs are deadon parodies) and Scary Movie-style joke-throwing.

version.name: Sky of Love
version.review: A friendship between two students who attend the same school turns into a romance. The only problem is, they may not necessarily exist in the same world. In Cantonese with English subtitles.

version.name: Shattered
version.review: Why is it whenever theres a movie about a detective and a serial killer, their lives seem to intertwine in ways that would never occur in real life? In this film, Detective Matt Connolly (Scanlan) is put in charge of hunting down a serial killer who has murdered a number of young women. As the plot thickens, Connolly and killer get too close for comfort.

version.name: Persepolis
version.review:
This animated feature is a conflation of Iranian writer Satrapis four graphic novels that detail with wry humour her childhood in late 1970s and 80s Tehran, her schooldays in Vienna, her return to Iran, her university and a failed marriage and, finally, her decision in her mid-twenties to leave home and move to Paris. The film retains the monochrome of the comics, mixing a stark black-and-white style with softer, round edges and a playful approach to character and movement. Satrapis analysis of her journeys between Middle East and West is mostly funny and fascinating, not least when she describes how she left behind the solemnity of the Iran-Iraq war to face the comfortable nonchalance of Austrias middle-class teenagers. Later, the film struggles to maintain its early humour and rushes to cover too much ground, but most endearing is the relationship between Satrapi (Mastroianni) and her grandmother (Darrieux).
Read our review of Persepolis

version.name: One Foot Off the Ground
version.review: A struggling opera troupe is forced to live in the real world after being self-contained in a company led by diva Sumei (Xu). After disbanding, the individual members of the troupe barely get by, forced to face the harshness of life beyond the stage. In Mandarin with English subtitles

version.name: The Old Garden
version.review: In this political melodrama, a social activist seeks refuge in a mountain village a few months after the Gwangju massacre in the 1980s. There he seeks comfort in the arms of his teacher/girlfriend. But when he leaves to join the student rebellion, hes arrested almost immediately

version.name: Meet the Spartans
version.review: Much was made of the gay subtext in last years 300. Honestly, though, what was the big deal? Actual Spartan warriors reportedly engaged in tons of sweaty man-love in between bouts of brutal killing it was the Spartan way. The gay jokes are as numerous as the sun-blotting Persian arrows in this harebrained spoof that features dance-offs, hot-in-the-90s Carmen Electra, lots of bad topical jokes and an awesome former C-list television star: Kevin Sorbo. The films finest moment occurs when Captain (Sorbo) exclaims, Im gonna go Hercules on his ass. Ugh. (Drew Toal)

version.name: Jumper
version.review: For those whove seen Roland Emmerichs 1994 sci-fi adventure Stargate, the premise for this film isnt new. Adapted from Steven Goulds novels about people who can transport themselves through space and time, and those who swear to kill them, Jumper brings on board big names like Christensen, Jackson and Lane to take off. Photo 20th Century Fox.

version.name: The House
version.review: Joe, an architecture student, is literally saved by a house. After the death of his parents, hes left homeless, degree-less and psychologically numb. As fate would have it, he finds his way to the house and meets a group of young bohemian squatters. There, he meets people in pretty hopeless situations and finds his place.

version.name: Feast of Love
version.review: The plot involves three different couples at various stages in their lives. Freeman and Alexanders love is being tested by the shocking loss of their adult son to heroin addiction. Kinnear bumbles out of a marriage to a lesbian finally finding herself (Blair) and then falls into a relationship with a gorgeous woman (Mitchell) who conceals from him her ongoing fling with a married cad (Billy Burke). Hemingway and Davalos are a teenage couple who love so intensely you know theyre doomed. (Hank Sartin)

version.name: The Eye
version.review: Yet another big-budget, big-name Hollywood remake of an Asian winning formula. For those of you who missed the original Hong Kong production, the plot follows a girl who receives an eye transplant only to realise she has gained more than just plain sight. Photo Lionsgate films.

version.name: CJ7
version.review: If you caught the trailer, youd be able to guess that Chow and his antics are back after the brilliant Kung Fu Hustle. Here Chow gives the science-fiction genre a strange and hilarious twist (then again, when has he ever played it straight?). The actor-director stars as a man who lives in a decrepit house and takes in a homeless boy. When he finds a toy in a heap of garbage, he brings it back to his son, unaware that the toy is actually an alien. Photo Sony Pictures.

movie.name: The Assassination of Jesse James by the Coward Robert Ford

version.name: The Assassination of Jesse James by the Coward Robert Ford
version.review: Possibly bloody itself from an editing-room showdown, this long-gestating adaptation of Ron Hansens novel reportedly prompted a conflict of visions: Precocious second-time director Dominik (Chopper) wanted to make a Terrence Malick movie, while studio bigwigs crossed their fingers and prayed for the second coming of Unforgiven. The finished film feels like a tradeoff between the two. Assassination meanders through an hour of awkward lyricism before getting to the real meat: the titular mano a mano between ageing outlaw Jesse James (Pitt) and would-be sidekick Bob Ford (Affleck), who eventually took out his hero albeit in an act of self-preservation while James straightened a picture. (Ben Kenigsberg)
version.property: NC16 - No children under the age of 16

version.name: American Gangster
version.review: Read our review of American Gangster here.
version.property: M18 - No one under the age of 18 admitted

version.name: Redline
version.review: A gorgeous and succulent automobile fanatic finds herself caught up in an illegal drag-racing competition organised by a bunch of rich daddys boys. If what youre chasing after are hot chicks and fast cars, then rev up to your nearest cinema. But if youre looking for something with an ounce of substance, steer clear of this one.

version.name: The Savages
version.review: See our review of The Savages here. See our interview with Laura Linney here.

version.name: Penny Dreadful
version.review: Penny (Miner) goes on a retreat with her therapist in hopes of eradicating her phobia of cars. Down the road, unexpected events take place, sending Penny crashing into her worst fears.

version.name: My Blueberry Nights
version.review: 2046 marked something of a summation of Cannes darling Wong Kar-wais Hong Kong-based career to date, so his English-language debut is highly anticipated. With this tale of a waitress on a vocational voyage of discovery across the United States of America, Wong has certainly embraced a new landscape: shooting has ranged from New York to Nevada to Tennessee. Singer Norah Jones makes her acting debut.

version.name: Le Grand Chef
version.review: Based on a manga series of the same title, Le Grand Chef tells the story of two young chefs cooking up a storm in competition to out-cook each another.

version.name: Kite Runner
version.review: Forster adapts Khaled Hosseinis bestseller about two boys in Afghanistan whose lives are changed when one of them is raped.

version.name: The Darjeeling Limited
version.review: Father-related family trauma spiced with fraternal rivalry? Animalthemed whimsy? Owen Wilson and Jason Schwartzman? Yes, its the latest from Wes Anderson, about three brothers on a journey through India with a hunch their late dad has been reincarnated as an albino leopard. Expect plaintive guitar rock and sad-eyed absurdity aplenty.

version.name: Cloverfield
version.review: From the creator of Lost, JJ Abrams, comes a monster movie in which New York City gets attacked by a mysterious creature. The Statue of Liberty loses her head as the city goes into chaos.

version.name: The Book of Revelation
version.review: Three masked women abduct a male dancer. After being sexually and psychically abused, hes thrown back on the streets, a broken man. Unable to confide in his girlfriend, he struggles to pick up the pieces and track down the women responsible for his downfall.

version.name: Boogeyman 2
version.review: AWs Tobin Bell is back to instill fear yet again in the sequel to 2005s Boogeyman. A young woman (Savre) checks herself into a mental hospital after being plagued by visions of the childhood terror. But what she finds inside only proves that nightmares really do come true.

version.name: Atonement
version.review:
On the hottest day of the summer of 1935, 13-year-old Briony Tallis (Ronan) sees her older sister Cecilia (Knightley) strip off and plunge into the fountain in the garden of their country house. Watching Cecilia is their housekeepers son Robbie Turner (McAvoy), a childhood friend who, along with Brionys sister, has recently graduated from Cambridge. By the end of that day, the lives of all three have changed forever. Robbie and Cecilia cross a boundary they had never dared to approach and become victims of the younger girls scheming imagination, while Briony commits a dreadful crime, the subsequent guilt haunting her entire life. Adapted from Ian McEwans novel, its been nominated for several awards. Read our interview with director Joshua Rothkopf.
Photo Focus Features.

version.name: Warlords
version.review:
In this heroic tale, three brothers played by threeokay, two very good-looking Asian men, struggle in the midst of war and political upheaval during the Qing Dynasty and the attempt on General Ma Xinyis life.
In Mandarin with English subtitles.

version.name: The Tattooist
version.review: If youve ever considered inking an ethnic tattoo, let this be a cautionary tale. Jake Sawyer (Behr) is a tattoo artist who wanders the world in search of inspiration for his designs. While at a tattoo expo in Singapore, he stumbles upon the exotic world of traditional Samoan tattoo (tatau). When unfortunate events start to happen, Jake must find a way to save his lover, Sina (Blake), and recover his own soul.

version.name: P2
version.review: Its interesting to see how directors come up with pre- or post-Christmas plots to stand out from the usual holiday fare. In this thriller, corporate climber Angela (Nichols) ends up working late on Christmas Eve. All alone in a big office and pursued by a crazy security guard (Bentley), Angela must overcome her physical and psychological challenges to survive. And we think a crowded mall with last-minute shoppers is bad.

version.name: The Orphanage
version.review: Produced by Guillermo del Toro (Pans Labyrinth), this is a psychologically complex tale of stolen childhood innocence. While Laura (Rueda) and her husband Carlos (Cayo) renovate the orphanage where she herself grew up, her adopted son Simón (Príncep) forms a mysterious relationship with a group of imaginary friends, one of whom he draws with a creepy, scarecrow-like hood over his face. When Simón later disappears, Laura believes his fate is somehow linked to that of the five children with whom she spent her own early years. (Nigel Floyd)

version.name: The Mist
version.review: Based on a novel by Stephen King, The Mist fogs the line between fact and fiction when a small town is hit by a freak storm of bloodthirsty creatures.

version.name: Mad Detective
version.review: In another tag-team thriller, a rookie cop is thrown in the deep end when hes teamed up with a former colleague to bring a serial killer to justice.

version.name: I Am Legend
version.review: A mutated virus turns the worlds populace into bloodthirsty monsters everyone, that is, except for former military scientist Robert Neville (Smith). Living in quarantine on Manhattan island, Neville works day and night to find a cure before the creatures devour him.

version.name: The Heartbreak Kid
version.review: Loosely based on a screenplay by New York City bard Neil Simon, The Heartbreak Kid follows the lovelorn antics of arch singleton Eddie Cantrow (Stiller). At the insistence of his friends and family, Eddie puts his various commitment issues on hold and chooses to embark on a whirlwind romance with Lila (Akerman), a kooky blonde he meets outside a Laundromat. As quick as you can say, Hang on, isnt this the 40-Year-Old Virgin?, theyre waltzing arm-in-arm down the aisle and headed for a life of wedded bliss. Its en route to their honeymoon in Mexico, however, that the nightmare begins, as Lila via a 180° change of character decides to slowly reveal the details of her sordid past. (David Jenkins)

version.name: The Flock
version.review: Gere remains versatile in his roles. In this new thriller, he puts on the face of a vigilante in search of a sex offender on parole. While training his young replacement Allison (Danes), the unlikely pair unravels twisted details linking a missing girl to Geres prey.

version.name: Death Sentence
version.review: A multi-racial crew of one-dimensional thugs slaughter corporate guy Bacons beloved son in a gang-initiation rite. Bacon turns vigilante, then finds himself in way over his head. Its efficient by-the-numbers revengesploitation enlivened by some jim-dandy action set pieces and the odd jolt of humour, some of it intentional. John Goodman is a hoot as the black-market gun dealer who sells Bacon his ordnance. Underexposed cinematography gives everybody a nice corpse-y look even before the blood begins to flow. If you feel like giving your baser instincts a workout, you could do worse. (Cliff Doerksen)

version.name: Assembly
version.review: Feng, director of The Banquet, brings the themes of war and greed to the frontline in this tale of one captains undying efforts to return honour to his men who died at the height of the Huaihai Campaign during the Chinese Civil War in 1948.

version.name: Alvin and the Chipmunks
version.review: Do you remember the last time you sang the line Were the Chipmunks. Alvin, Simon, Theodore? Well, we do. This popular cartoon series from the 80s has gotten a makeover, live action/CGI style.

version.name: Michael Clayton
version.review: Dir Tony Gilroy 2007. USA. 120 mins. George Clooney, Sean Cullen, Tom Wilkinson, Tilda Swinton, Sydney Pollack.

version.name: In the Valley of Elah
version.review: Paul Haggiss state-of-the-nation whodunit about a retired Army lieutenant (Jones) searching for his MIA soldier son isnt likely to sway the few and the proud who still think the occupation of Iraq is justified. Nor will this angry screed, trumpeting the moral that war dehumanises everyone who participates in it, seem like anything but preaching to the choir for politically progressive audience members. The one thing the movie does extraordinarily well, however, is demonstrate how a truly great actor can lift up a mediocre film. (David Fear)

version.name: The Golden Compass
version.review: Based on Philip Pullmans best-selling novel, The Golden Compass is a fantasy adventure set in a parallel universe where peoples souls manifest themselves as creatures, talking bears fight wars and children are mysteriously going missing. The story revolves around 12-year-old Lyra (Richards), who sets out to find and rescue her best friend Roger (Walker), and ends up on a magical quest to save not only her world, but ours as well. See Golden ticket.

version.name: 30 Days of Night
version.review: This broadly faithful but chronically uneven adaptation of Steve Niles and Ben...

version.name: The Game Plan
version.review:
Following in the testosterone-sculpted footsteps of Vin Diesel and the Governator, former WWE champ Dwayne Johnson (The Rock) tackles a Disney romp about a tyke-challenged muscleman. Fans of The Rocks comic chops and considerable Samoan charm might be tickled by his turn as an egocentric quarterback suddenly confronted with an eight-year-old daughter he unwittingly fathered. But this Hail Mary pass at a pro-American football family comedy fumbles logic and reason for the sake of sass attacks and trumpedup kiddie trauma.
Stephen Garrett

version.name: December Boys
version.review:
Four Australian orphans are treated to a Christmas vacation at a remote beach community, and all we got was this treacly, loopy movie. It takes a bold or tin-eared writer to include in one film: a teen romance; a woman dying of cancer; a couple who cant have children and weigh adoption; a grizzled fisherman and the giant fish hes been trying to catch for years; a wild horse who wanders in and out of the plot like a big symbolic whatsit; and a guy lying about being a circus performer to impress people. Its as if four or five different movies are battling for attention.
The four orphans (Radcliffe, Byers, Cormie, Fraser) dream of being taken away by new parents, though Radcliffes character, Maps (they all have cute nicknames), is pragmatic enough to know that when your balls drop, so do your chances of being adopted. So while the other three spend their holiday competing to see who can charm the childless couple (Hill and Stapleton) and win the adoption sweepstakes, Radcliffe gets a romance with Palmer, the only other teen for miles, who is conveniently hot to trot and has a cool record collection. Meanwhile, the lovable older couple hosting the orphans (Thompson and McQuade) deal with the wifes impending death, the fisherman dreams big fishy dreams, and the pony makes cameos.
With so many threads and so little time, Hardy and his editor cut between scenes with a jumpiness that suggests theres another hour of material on the cutting-room floor. Not that we want to see any of it.
Hank Sartin

version.name: Saawariya
version.review: Based on a short story by Fyodor Dostoevsky (White Nights), this short film tells the story of a 26-year-old whos a romantic at heart. He meets a girl and the story is based on the four nights the two spend together. With a beautiful soundtrack and romance, this is a perfect date movie.

version.name: Lust, Caution
version.review: The title Lust, Caution promises an emotional conflict, but Lees follow-up to Brokeback Mountain swings violently between the two modes, offering more than an hour of restrained espionage drama hushed phone calls, secret assassination plans, several rounds of mahjong before plunging headlong into its Verhoeven-calibre sex scenes. Regarding those: courting disproportionate hype, Lee has stressed the importance of the sex for character development, which makes sense if, as here, your characters are woefully underdeveloped.
version.property: NC16 - No children under the age of 16

version.name: Hitman
version.review: Based on a popular video game, Olyphant plays assassin-for-hire Agent 47. A conspiracy lands him in dire straits and both Interpol and the Russian military pursue him. When the hunter becomes the hunted, Agent 47 does what he does best kill, kill and kill some more.
version.property: NC16 - No children under the age of 16

version.name: Good Luck Chuck
version.review: You know how Judd Apatow has shown a genius for being foul-mouthed but wonderfully loving of his characters in 40-Year-Old Virgin and Knocked Up? Leave the foulmouthed, throw in a lot of naked breasts, and take away the humanity and the humour. Presto! Youve got this pool of cinematic sewage, in which Cook plays a guy whos been cursed with being the last man any woman sleeps with before finding true love.
version.property: R21 - No one under the age of 21 admitted

version.name: Enchanted
version.review: Sarandon plays a wicked fairy-tale queen who banishes a young princess (Adams) from her world of classical animation to a modern-day Manhattan. And naturally the princess begins to change her views on life and love after meeting a handsome lawyer (Dempsey). Heres the ultimate question: can a storybook romance survive in the real world?

version.name: Beowulf
version.review: Based on a screenplay by fantasy scribe Neil Gaiman and Roger Avary, this legend tells of the mighty warrior Beowulf (Winstone), who battles the demon Grendel (Glover), and incurs the wrath of the seductive Queen played by the beautiful adoption-junkie Angelina Jolie.

version.name: Evening
version.review: The pedigree on this drama is impressive: its based on a respected Susan Minot novel, the screenplay is by Pulitzer-winner Michael Cunningham (The Hours), its directed by noted cinematographer turned- director Lajos Koltai (Fateless), and the cast is like a multi-generation summit conference of notable women. The resulting film, alas, looks distressingly like an ad for a sleep aid, complete with butterflies and fields of tall grass. Dying Ann Lord (Redgrave) recalls in golden-hued flashbacks her great mistake, which involved not marrying a blandly hunky doctor she met at the ritzy Newport, Rhode Island, wedding of her best friend in the 1950s. During the weekend, the younger Ann (Danes, pleasant but unimpressive) flirts with the doctor (Wilson, barely registering a pulse) when shes not propping up her supposed date for the weekend, an alcoholic who hasnt yet come to terms with his obvious homosexuality (Dancy, more interesting than the role hes stuck in). Guess which character gets sacrificed to the gods of melodramatic plotting. Meanwhile, in the present, Anns daughters (Collette, Richardson) deal with her impending death. Koltai and cinematographer Gyula Pados paint pretty pictures, but this film is about as exciting as watching a particularly tasteful shade of paint dry. Theres mild interest in the fact that the film has several mother-daughter pairs among the cast (Redgrave and Richardson, Streep and Gummer), but it cant be a good sign that this fact is worth mentioning. Hank Sartin

version.name: Eastern Promises
version.review: Cronenberg re-teams with his History of Violence star Viggo Mortensen for this London-set tale of the Russian Mafia, revolving around the sex trade. See Renaissance Man.

version.name: Voice of a Murderer
version.review: In this melodrama, the nine-year-old son of popular news anchor Han (Sol) gets kidnapped. As the police bicker over voice recognition devices, the folks put on a display of parental hysteria.

version.name: Unrest
version.review: Abra Cadaver! A corpse comes alive in this gruesome horror flick about a woman studying to be a physician, only to encounter an aroused anatomy.

version.name: Truth Be Told
version.review: MediaCorp artiste Yvonne Lim plays a woman who returns to Singapore when a new job as a television producer beckons. On her first day, she is faced with a past she ran away from ten years before she bumps into her old neighbour, Old Teo (Liang), during a shoot for a current-affairs assignment.

version.name: Triangle
version.review: Three of Hong Kongs cult directors play a game of round-robin by helming one segment each of about 30 to 35 minutes. The plot basically revolves around three drinking buddies all in need of a quick buck. The men decide to rob a bank, but plans change when a mysterious stranger spills the beans about a box hidden under the Hong Kong Legislative containing an ancient Tang-dynasty relic.

version.name: Trade
version.review: Jorge (Ramos) is 17 and on a mission to rescue his younger sister whos been abducted by sex traffickers in Mexico City. Lets hope Jorge is a Mexican and not a Mexicant.

version.name: The Ten Commandments
version.review: With its own website (www.epicstoriesofthebible.com) replete with wallpapers, printable posters and resources to download, this is more than just a film, its a riot for schools and churches. The storyline is the same, the only difference is this film pays more attention to Mosess family, both real and extended.

version.name: Superbad
version.review:
With Judd Apatows comedy crusade in full swing thanks to Knocked Up, its only a matter of time before his gentle, geeky characters nuzzle up to a popular backlash quite possibly from Apatows blind spot, women. So call these the salad days, with Superbad the peak of Dorkus primus. Certainly as long as there are movies, there will be pre-collegiate summer-of-getting-laid romps involving the acquisition of beer, babes and, ultimately, wisdom. But even the gang from Revenge of the Nerds will appear Rat Pack-ready compared with Superbads sweaty squad: mouth-breather Seth (Hill); intense, anaemic Evan (Cera); and their awkward third wheel, a bespectacled wanksta named Fogell (Mintz-Plasse), aka McLovin.
Of course, their exploits which transpire over one night are adorably awkward. (The co-writers are childhood friends Evan Goldberg and Knocked Ups Seth Rogen; note those first names.) This is comedy of a liberating nature, about the various indignities that coolness always requires, be it drunkenly smacking your head into an interested girls face or befriending a group of basement coke-heads who insist that you sing soul music. When Superbad pokes fun at that pointlessness, its endearing. Beyond the central bickering trio, though, there are gauzy areas, such as a pair of clueless cops and the usual lust objects. Perhaps its best to regard this movie as it sees itself: a drunken, inept, parking-lot joyride set to Van Halens Panama, 20 years after that song was cool. Was it ever cool? Aw yeah.
Joshua Rothkopf

version.name: Silk
version.review: Based on a novel by Alessandro Barricco, this film tells the story of a married silkworm smuggler, Herve Joncour (Pitt), who travels to Japan to collect cargo. There he meets the beautiful concubine of a local baron played by Yakusho. They fall in love, despite the language barrier and respective other-halves.

movie.name: The Seeker: The Dark Is Rising

version.name: The Seeker: The Dark Is Rising
version.review: As a young man, Will Stanton (Ludwig) has more than puberty and relationships to worry about. Hes the last of a group of warriors who have dedicated their lives to fighting the forces of darkness.

version.name: Muay Thai Chaiya
version.review: Set in mid-70s Thailand, three boys aspire to be boxing champions. When one of them uncovers an old manuscript of Muay Thai Chaiya secrets left behind by his father, the three friends are inspired and take on the ancient martial art form. The boys get sidetracked when pretty nurse Sriprai (Kongpech) enters the scene.

version.name: Lars and the Real Girl
version.review: Ryan Gosling is back after the highly acclaimed Half Nelson. This time he stars as a young man who befriends a female doll over the internet. When he takes this relationship out of cyberspace, his loved ones stage an intervention.

version.name: The Italian
version.review:
You cant be blamed for seeing The Italians underage lead a blond Euromoppet with a face that could grace a Campbells soup can and thinking that you were in for cherub-cinema sugar shock. But Kolya this isnt; Andrei Kravchuk hews closer to the spirit of Germany Year Zero (1948, Roberto Rossellini) and Shoeshine (1946, Vittorio De Sica), two movies that wrench your heart, yet never sink under the weight of their own street-urchin tragedies.
At the Dickensian orphanage he calls home, Vanya (Spiridonov) hits the jackpot: an Italian couple wants to adopt him. Then a friends birth mother shows up, and Vanyas mind starts to think about his own mother returning to look for him. After sneaking a peek at his fi le, Vanya hits the road. The house madam (Kuznetsova), who doesnt like losing commissions, is hot on the boys trail.
Surprisingly, the grimy landscapes and grubby characters dont automatically qualify Kravchuks drama as a downer; theres an underwhelming slightness to the dour aspects that plays against the prematurely toughened, street-smart youth. But while muted scenarios are always preferable to blatant manipulation, The Italian isnt entirely satisfying. The movies sheen of desperation is ultimately like a shabby coat that, once a hint of sunshine shows up, is too easily discarded.
DF

version.name: Halloween
version.review: Michael Myers (Mane) returns for more blood-squirting, scream-inducing mayhem. Estranged and mentally unstable, hes back for his little sister after butchering the elder one back in 1963. For Laurie Strode (Taylor-Compton), this Halloween isnt about trick or treat, but life or death.

version.name: Grace Is Gone
version.review: In this touching tale, Cusack plays a father who has a job at a home-supply store while his wife fights in Iraq. When tragedy strikes, he decides to take his daughters on a road trip with the intention of breaking the news to them gently.

version.name: The Ferryman
version.review: A group of twentysomethings take a vacation on a boat to Fiji. During the journey, they stumble upon a spirit that vows vengeance at all costs. Bet the unsuspecting victims didnt expect that in the itinerary.

version.name: Dead Daughters
version.review: Talk about the karma police: this horror flick sets the scene in present-day Moscow. The ghosts of three dead daughters pick a person at random and watch them for three days. If during this probation period the persons moral standards appear questionable, the daughters then kill him using telekinesis.

version.name: Day Watch
version.review:
A Frankensteins monster of leftovers from The Matrix, Tolkiens Middle-earth epics and Magic: The Gathering cards, Timur Bekmambetovs Night Watch (2004) wasnt just an adaptation of Sergei Lukyanenko and Vladimir Vasilievs mega-popular novels. It was also Russias attempt to outdo Hollywood with its own homegrown blockbuster borscht a gambit that translated into mad rubles at the box office.
This sequel reprises the originals concept that if you just throw a lot of cool fantasy ballyhoo together, who cares if coherence becomes collateral damage? Day Watch is what youd imagine its like being stuck inside the head of a geeky 12- year-old boy. Vampires duke it out with super-cops and medieval barbarians, generic nü-metal riffs and DJ breakbeats play in constant loops, and doe-eyed hotties strut around in fetish wear. All thats missing is a bitchin Fast and the Furious-style joyride. Actually, scratch that; thats in there as well.
The plot? Once again, the dark others and light others are on the verge of starting the apocalypse, this time over the One Ring sorry, the Chalk of Fate, which will decide whether evil or good wins. Bekmambetov is currently at work on a third instalment; perhaps its time to just say nyet.
David Fear

version.name: The Brave One
version.review: Foster stars as a woman who takes justice into her own hands after her fiancé (Andrews) is beaten to death by thugs. Terrence Howard is the detective on her trail.

version.name: Balls of Fury
version.review: Randy Daytona (Fogler), a washed-up ping-pong prodigy with an affinity for Def Leppard, embarks on a quest to help the FBI put the screws to Triad kingpin Mr. Feng (Walken) and, by extension, avenge his fathers murder. The government uses Randys rarefied skill set to infiltrate Fengs remote island fortress, where each year this enigmatic malefactor hosts an Enter the Dragon-style table-tennis tournament. Predictably absurd, Balls of Fury employs enough comedic talent Diedrich Bader is brilliant as Fengs sex slave to make all the lame spoofing translate into some legitimate laughs. (Drew Toal)

version.name: Angel
version.review:
Based on the novel by British author Elizabeth Taylor, this drama is set in England in 1905. Angel Deverell is a gifted young writer who dreams of success, fame and love. But what will happen if all her dreams come true? Angel is a destitute but determined young woman who ascends the social ranks after authoring a series of successful romantic novels. This is the story of a young woman with incredible imagination who refuses to accept the world about her, and creates her own realities.
Where: Alliance Française de Singapour When: 21 Jul; 8pm
version.property: M18 - No one under the age of 18 admitted

version.name: The 11th Hour
version.review: After all the published studies and consciousness-raising concerts, is there anybody who still isnt convinced that our big blue marble is going to hell in a hand-basket? This hectoring ecomentary lays out a litany of testimonials to sway the handful that consider global warming either neoliberal whining or a nonexistent threat. A number of independent experts on the front line a term that encompasses everybody from tribal faith-keepers to Stephen Hawking theorise that the recent abundance of natural disasters is symptomatic of a larger global breakdown. Corporate interests (cue booing, hissing) have also contributed to untold environmental damage, and human beings must fi nd alternative methods to help an infected Mother Earth. The sky may not be falling, but the rest of the planet is pretty f****d. Nadia Conners and Leila Conners Petersens solar-powered jalopy of a doc, however, isnt a vehicle thats likely to bring this message to the masses. The duo employs a numbing repetition of form talking-head interviews, news footage, rinse, repeat and constantly recycled factoids that grate over time. If theres a lesson to be learned from The 11th Hour, its that a good cause presented without grace ultimately becomes a lost cause.

version.name: Resident Evil: Extinction
version.review: The final part of the videogame-derived Resident Evil trilogy is the least boring. Faint praise, perhaps, but one must be grateful for small mercies. Based on a script by series creator Paul WS Anderson, Australian director Russell Mulcahys post-apocalyptic movie owes much to countryman George Millers Mad Max movies. The corpse-regenerating T-Virus, which in the last instalment escaped from the Umbrella Corporations underground laboratory to infect the whole of Raccoon City, has now spread across the entire United States. Superhuman Alice (Milla Jovovich) a beautiful but rebellious by-product of the corporations search for an antidote joins a convoy of vehicles driven by a ragtag band of human survivors. The crazed Dr Isaacs (Iain Glen) keeps an eye on them, using the corporations all-seeing satellite surveillance system, as they roam the Nevada desert and sand-swept Las Vegas streets in search of food, water and fuel. Until Alice decides its time to settle the score with her mad-scientist creator once and for all. The plot is every bit as episodic and nonsensical as before, but Extinction ups the ante by introducing some new and/or improved adversaries: a murder of mutant crows, who prefer live flesh to carrion; a new breed of killer dogs; Super Undead zombies that are more fleet of foot; and a squidgy, tentacled monster called The Tyrant. Amid the choreographed fights, loud explosions and CG creatures, there are some new and old faces. But the scariest visage is that of Alice, whose flawless, airbrushed complexion is either a throwback to Mulcahys New Romantic pop promos or something dictated by Jovovichs LOréal contract.

version.name: The Willow Tree
version.review: The âbe careful what you wish forâ maxim is easily applicable to all timeworn conventions. What redeems The Willow Tree from collapsing into complete melodrama is director Majid Majidiâs preternatural ability to capture the worldâs ethereal dimensions. This filmâs cautionary tale may look bathetic â but just as its protagonist discovers, looks are deceiving. Majidi first used blindness as a premise in The Color of Paradise (1999), featuring a sightless boy with a father embarrassed by his sonâs lack of vision. This time around, the blind character is Youssef (Parastui), a middle-aged professor who could see when he was a child. Happily married with a daughter, Youssef still harbours resentment toward God for taking his vision â until a medical procedure in Paris restores his sight. And thatâs when the trouble begins. The Willow Tree works as a metaphor for how different cultures give people a keener view of their own lives, or as a warning to those who invest all their hopes into one myopic dream, or even as a test of religious devotion. The film has its flaws (Majidi, a winner of the 2001 Hamburg Film Festivalâs Douglas Sirk Award, tends toward the maudlin), but his gift for giving a cinematic texture to the emotional senses validates his work as a visionary. Stephen Garrett

version.name: Waitress
version.review: Her husbandâs a frightening, chauvinist pig; her boar-faced boss at the dinerâs a monosyllabic tyrant; and sheâs seven weeks overdue â but boy, can perky, pretty, pinafore-ed, Picayune princess Jenna (Keri Russell) bake a cherry pie!

version.name: Sumolah
version.review: In this comedy, good-for-nothing Ramlee ends up working in a sushi restaurant, only to realise he is to represent the restaurant in an underground sumo-wrestling tournament. Fight Club minus the mind games plus a few laughs.

version.name: Sugar and Spice
version.review: Rebellious 17-year-old Shiro (Yagira)takes on a job as a petrol station attendant in an attempt to defy his parents. There hemeets and falls in love with an older andmore experienced Noriko (Sawajiri). Shirohopes to de-virginalise himself and cross intomanhood, but not if his grandma can help it.

version.name: Rogue Assassin
version.review: After his partner and family is killed by Rogue (Li), FBI agent Jack Crawford (Statham) becomes obsessed with hunting the killer down. Crawfordâs life soon spirals into a web of revenge, guilt and betrayal.

version.name: No Reservations
version.review: The rom-com formula gets a weirdly subdued treatment from Hicks (the good Shine, the bad Snow Falling on Cedars). Zeta-Jones plays Kate Armstrong, a successful but overly work-oriented chef in a New York bistro. Sheâs so driven that her boss (Clarkson) insists that she see a shrink (Balaban). Kate is that old clichÃ©: the professional woman who needs to be loosened up by the love of a man with an overabundance of joie de vivre. Sure enough, into her life walks Nick (Eckhart), a chef who she thinks is trying to take her job. He leads the kitchen staff in singalongs, tells funny stories and generally makes her seem like an uptight bitch. What throws this script off the usual rom-com path is the presence of Kateâs niece Zoe (Breslin), whom Kate must take care of after a car accident kills Zoeâs mum. Kate has to learn how to adjust her life to include a grieving little girl, while also juggling a kitchen rivalry-turnedromance. Both relationships are meant to teach Kate to lighten up and take life as it comes. (Why must Hollywood continue to punish professional women for being successful?) Itâs perfectly harmless and intermittently moving, but the leads are both oddly miscast. Zeta-Jones delivers a monologue about the proper preparation of quail with the seductive but neutral clarity of an advertising spokeswoman, but we never fully buy her passion for food. And Eckhart telegraphs Nickâs âquirky charmâ, but gives the distinct feeling that he was thrown into a role written for someone else. Things work themselves out, tears and laughs are called forth at appropriate intervals, and all youâre likely to muster when the credits roll is a shrug. Hank Sartin

version.name: Joshua
version.review: An intelligent, urbane spin on the evil-tyke thriller, Ratliffâs latest stays with you â largely due to its many strong performances, especially from Sam Rockwell and Vera Farmiga as befuddled parents.

version.name: I Know Who Killed Me
version.review: Now would be the perfect moment for Lindsay Lohan to knock us out with the kind of performance sheâs capable of. As it happens, this bizarre thriller is ten times more fascinating as an accidental piece of private exposure, one that ends with Lohan literally digging her own grave to find another dark-haired, husky starlet staring up at her. A hallucinatory psychodrama that owes more to Mulholland Drive than to Captivity, the movie has Lohan straddling two roles (as in life): good girl Aubrey, a piano student and football playerâs crush, suffers a particularly gruesome abduction that costs her an arm and a leg; she then takes on the identity of bad girl Dakota, a former pole dancer and maneater. Aubreyâs parents tear themselves apart during her unraveling, detectives scowl, and âDakotaâ decides to hobble her way to her torturerâs identity. The imagery is fi lled with feverish symbols of lost potency: multiple hand-loppings, a hairless cat, Lohanâs own excessive profanity and desperate grinding. I donât attribute a creative intelligence to such a perfect match of material and actor â how would Lohan even know to choose it? But this will undoubtedly be the key film of her career: a scared expression of total meltdown.

version.name: Hwang Jin-yi
version.review: This film is based on the story of the famous 16th-century Gisaeng (a female Korean entertainer comparable to a Japanese Geisha). This movie celebrates Jin-yiâs beauty, intelligence, charm and love for her art.

version.name: Hairspray
version.review: Letâs get one thing clear: there is nothing questionable about heterosexual actor John Travolta clad in a fat suit, dragged up in pink sequins and breathily trilling âIâm the cutest chickie that you ever did see!â There is, however, something awkward and faintly disturbing about watching his Edna Turnblad dance and duet with Christopher Walkenâs Mr Turnblad dressed in toreador kitsch. Divine it ainât. In fact, so peculiarly mannered is Ednaâs transformation from chipmunky homebody to liberated blob that itâs quite impossible to forget youâre watching John Travolta in latex and, therefore, to suspend disbelief. Nor is that made any easier by uncertain, sometimes clashing performances from such other big names as Michelle Pfeiffer, Queen Latifah and indeed Walken, whose dance skills are criminally underused. That said, this new Hairspray â adapted from the Broadway musical based on the 1988 film â is often great fun. Though not as scabrous, as sharp or even as musically memorable as John Watersâ original, it retains much of his filthy, big-hearted sensibility (he cameos as a happy flasher) and is less deadeningly stagey than that other recent fi lm-of-the-musical-of-the-film, The Producers. Ben Walters

Stephen King, the author of this source material, has already done haunted hotels. So the idea of stretching what was simply supposed to be a dessert course (a short story in Kingâs 2000 audiobook âBlood and Smokeâ) to a full meal speaks more to Hollywood appetites than the proper dictates of drama. The tale is skimpy, mostly set in a New York City suite that, despite its bustling midtown location, is said to host unspeakable evil â and it doesnât even have Wi-Fi.

version.name: Whisper
version.review: The young son of one of the richestwomen in the state gets kidnapped forransom. In a creepy twist to Home Alone, theperpetrators soon realise that the boy isnt asinnocent as he seems.

version.name: Skinwalkers
version.review: When Timothy (Knight) turns 13, puberty hits in the form of grotesque transformations. Doting mum Rachel (Mitra) fears her sonâs health is in jeopardy. But the âSkinwalkersâ know of Timothyâs half-blooded heritage, and as the next full moon approaches, he will finally have the power to fulfil his familyâs destiny.

version.name: Secret
version.review: In his directorial debut, Jay Chou plays Lun, who on the first day of school is hypnotised by a mysterious piano solo coming from an old music room. He is anxious to find out the title of the piece, but thatâs theâ¦secret.

version.name: Pride
version.review: Jim Ellis (Howard), a charismatic schoolteacher, changes the lives of a group of black kids from Philadelphiaâs roughest neighborhoods when he forms an African-American swim team.

version.name: Planet Terror
version.review: In this hilarious parody of the bad sci-fi genre, a small-town sheriffâs department has to deal with the recent outbreak of zombie-like people known as the âsickosâ. Rose McGowan plays Cherry, an exotic dancer who realises her natural-born talent when she trades in a leg for an ass-kicking machine gun.

version.name: Perfect Stranger
version.review: A journalist gets in over her head chasing a possible serial-killer CEO in this paranoid thriller/corporate muck-raking drama/chatroom cautionary tale.

version.name: Nanking
version.review: Based on author Iris Changs TheRape of Nanking, the films script is builtfrom letters and memoirs, and read by actors.The documentarys visuals range fromsome of the most eye-popping war imageryto talking-head interviews with Japanesesoldiers. What sets this documentary apartis the fact that it highlights how a smallgroup of Western expatriates bandedtogether to save 250,000 lives.

version.name: The Home Song Stories
version.review: Rose (Chen) meets Bill (Vidler), an Australian sailor, and migrates to Victoria with her two children â Tom and May. The marriage is short-lived, Rose moves out with her two children and spends the next seven years working in Chinese restaurants. The Home Song Stories is ultimately a tale of mothers and sons, mothers and daughters, unrequited love, betrayal and secrets. Bring tissues.

version.name: Gone Shopping
version.review: A dark comedy about escapism through shopping. Retail therapy is the order of the day as Clara (Ng), a tragically romantic 40-year-old âtai taiâ, Renu (Nair), a feisty eight-year-old girl and Aaron (Kao), an angst ridden 23-year-old âGen-Yâ boy find refuge in a material world.

version.name: Flashpoint
version.review: This film features dangerous stunts without the fancy wire-work. Sound familiar? Well, itâs probably because this is the latest collaboration between director Wilson Yip and Donnie Yen, the same guys who brought you Kill Zone (2005).

version.name: The Drummer
version.review: Inspiredby a group of Zen drummers who live andtrain in deliberately primitive conditions ona mountain, this film is all about capturingand preserving a culture unknown to most.Jaycee Chan (son of Jackie) plays Sid, ayoung, low-level gangster forced to flee to themountains of Taiwan when he crosses hisboss.

version.name: Diva
version.review: Adored by everyone except the one person who matters most, Kartika (Baizura), a famous Malaysian diva, wishes to reach out to her mother. In hope of winning her motherâs affections, Kartika transforms students into great performers under the group, JIWA.

version.name: Contract Lover
version.review: Zao (Fan) is hired to be a temporary girlfriend to Fatt (Ren), who comes from a conservative family of martial arts experts. When Zao takes on the job and signs the contract, both her and Fatt are faced with the unexpected when they finally meet the folks. Oh what dramady!

version.name: Cashback
version.review: This British romantic comedy peers into the life of Ben Willis (Biggerstaff) after a painful breakup. Heartache-induced insomnia forces him to score a late-night shift at the local supermarket, where Benâs imagination goes wild. Able to stop time, he appreciates the artistic beauty of the frozen world and the people inside it, especially Sharon â the quiet checkout girl. A guarantee for fans of Kevin Smithâs Clerks and Terry Zwigoffâs Ghost World.

version.name: The Bourne Ultimatum
version.review: Inthe latest instalment of the espionage series,Jason Bourne hunts down his past in order tofind out what the future holds, all the whiletrying to outmanoeuvre the scores of cops,federal officers and Interpol agents whowould prefer him dead.

version.name: Apartment 1303
version.review: âWhite, bright and airy with sea views to boot.â Sounds like a househunterâs dream come trueâ¦but itâs more like a nightmare, as Sayaka soon realises. Something lurks in the bedroom closet, and itâs not a childish manifestation of the Boogeyman. What she finds is much worse â the spirit of a dead mother.

A kitschy musical about the Hungry Ghost Festival getai concerts directed by the reputed enfant terrible of Singapores film industry, Royston Tan.
In Mandarin, Hokkien, English and Cantonese with English subtitles Where: National Museum of Singapore Gallery Theatre When: 10 Jul; 11.30pm Costs: $8 (excluding SISTIC fee). This screening is held in conjunction with this years Night Festival
Image copyright: Zhao Wei Films

version.name: Hot Fuzz
version.review: A city cop investigates a series of grisly deaths in the seemingly sleepy village of Sandford.
version.property: NC16 - No children under the age of 16

version.name: Vacancy
version.review: When their car breaks down, a young couple stops at a local motel. And thatâs when the fun begins...!
version.property: NC16 - No children under the age of 16

version.name: The Simpsons Movie
version.review: Itâs taken 18 years, but The Simpsons, the phenomenally successful animated sitcom, has finally made the transition to the big screen. Homer, Marge, Bart, Lisa and Maggie appear with all your favourite characters, and the creators have promised one or two new ones. What little is known about the plot at this time involves the worst screw-up of Homerâs life. And, with his past record, it must be pretty bad.

version.name: Paprika
version.review:
Dir Satoshi Kon 2006. Japan. 90 mins. In Japanese, with subtitles. Voices of Megumi Hayashibara, Akio Otsuk.
Thereâs no shortage of intellectual concepts being bandied about in this anime tour of the subconscious by Satoshi Kon (Millennium Actress), which centers on a Cronenbergian device (picture a cross between an iPod and a dental tool) that can tap into dreams. Jungian notions of the collective unconscious collide into Media Studies 101 territory, debates rage about the disconnect between philosophy and technology, geopolitical sound bites are thrown in for good measure (âAll terrorists are desperateâ) and charactersâ REM cycles get the semiotic treatment. Japanâs manga masters have always taken their toons seriously, but this is the kind of sci-fithat practically requires a Ph.D. to fully appreciate.
Of course, nothing here is particularly easy to digest, which ends up being both a distinction and a curse. Paprikaâs narrative starts out fairly simple â someone has stolen the dream machine, a cop (Otsuka) and a therapist (Hayashibara) try to find out whodunit â and soon twists itself into labyrinthine loops. Even the doppelgÃ¤ngers start developing doppelgÃ¤ngers. Luckily, the sumptuous visual palette will blow your mind whether you can keep up or not, as parades of appliances and creepy-cutesy animals turn into elaborate psychedelic tableaux. Yet, like other overly ambitious anime, itâs all too much and not enough. Kon crams so many elements from modern J-cyberpulp, detective stories and The Chomsky Reader into the framework that by the end you can feel the seams bursting. When thereâs this much spice and food for thought on one plate, how are you expected to taste anything at all?

actor.actor-name: In Japanese with subtitles. Voices of Megumi Hayashibara

version.name: Martian Child
version.review: Traumatised by the passing of his fiancÃ©, John Cusack adopts a young boy who claims to be from Mars. The widowed science-fiction writer forms an unlikely family with a close friend (Amanda Peet) and Martian boy. Based on an award-winning short story by David Gerrold.

version.name: Knocked Up
version.review:
