Dir Judd Apatow 2006. USA. 129 mins. M18. Seth Rogen, Katherine Heigl, Paul Rudd.
A big, fat, gooey smile fixes itself to your face early on in Knocked Up, an impossibly sweet and unerringly sympathetic comedy of misfortune. As writer-director Judd Apatowâs follow-up to The 40 Year-Old Virgin, the movie also has the good sense to often be dorky. Apatowâs strength has always been his patience for freaks and geeks mustering confidence in a too-cool world. But what may make Knocked Up even more audacious than Virgin isnât just its neat reversal of the premise â these characters are a bit too lucky in the sack â but its elegant transition over the course of two hours into a rare realm of American humor, where comedy becomes philosophy.
Ben (Rogen, in a career-making performance) takes his habitual stoning and movie-tits ogling seriously â as does Alison (Heigl) her chirpy, blonde ascent to celebrity-interviewer quasi-stardom. Theyâre not meant to hook up, but thatâs exactly what happens one drunken night on the dance floor; two months later, what Ben assumes to be a booty call is actually a tense status report, each panicking into accusations. (Apatowâs ear for dialogue has, if anything, sharpened; he also ducks the obvious abortion angle with a bit of visual humor in front of an ultrasound that heralds stronger directing chops.) Deciding to grow into intimacy, the two eventually reach the demystified end of romance, the script adding realness with every turn. Ultimately the film says that fate has a way of kicking you up a notch, if you can somehow let yourself rise to the occasion (very scary, and not just to breeders). Apatow can certainly claim this to be true.
version.property: M18 - No one under the age of 18 admitted

version.name: Invisible City
version.review: In her newest film, director Tan Pin Pin (Singapore GaGa) explores the human condition â the desire to leave a mark before leaving this earth â on miniDV. From an avid amateur film director trying to preserve his decaying trove of Singapore footage, to an intrepid Japanese journalist hunting down Singaporean war veterans, Tan fleshes out the mundane, powerful emotions as the protagonists attempt immortality. For more details go to www.invisiblecity.sg.

movie.name: Harry Potter and the Order of the Phoenix

version.name: Harry Potter and the Order of the Phoenix
version.review: Daniel Radcliffe returns from appearing naked on the London stage in Equus, and Harry returns for a fifth year at Hogwarts School to discover that most of the wizard community is in denial about his recent encounter with Lord Voldemort. How convenient! Cornelius Fudge, the Minister for Magic, appoints yet another Defence Against the Dark Arts teacher to watch over the students, as he fears that the Hogwarts headmaster is lying about Voldemortâs return. Unfortunately, the newly appointed teacherâs ministry-approved course leaves the students unprepared and unable to defend themselves, so Harry takes matters into his own hands.

version.name: Die Hard 4.0
version.review: In this action-packed franchise revival, John McClane no longer works for the police department, but his job chasing down dangerous hackers for the Department of Homeland Security still places him directly in the line of fire. When an attack on Americaâs vulnerable infrastructure begins to shut down the entire nation, McClane is assigned the dangerous task of capturing the mysterious figure behind the act of terror and preventing chaos and catastrophe.

version.name: Dead Silence
version.review: In a fictional town called Ravens Fair, a ventriloquist named Mary Shaw went mad in the 1940s when she was accused of kidnapping a young boy who yelled out during one of her performances. She was subsequently hunted down and murdered by the townspeople as an act of revenge. Shaw is buried along with her âchildrenâ â her vaudeville dolls â and mysterious deaths start to plague the town when her collection decides to come back from the âdeadâ to seek revenge. With a tagline like âYou Scream. You Dieâ, one wonders how many Singaporeans will actually obey in silence.

version.name: The Condemned
version.review:
Dir Scott Wiper 2007. USA. 114mins. Steve Austin, Vinnie Jones, Rick Hoffman.
Opening with the ominous words, âa WWE Films productionâ, The Condemned can hardly be accused of straying from its core values. The pleasingly simple premise involves ten death-row inmates from around the world, including one played by wrestler Steve Austin (no longer Stone Cold, apparently), who are whisked away to an unnamed Pacific island where they will be made to fight to the death over the course of 30 hours, after which the sole survivor will be released. Holed up in a war room on the far end of the island, a small staff led by an egotistical young producer reminiscent of Girls Gone Wild creator Joe Francis, broadcasts the carnage live over the Internet and tracks the showâs âexposureâ on blogs and chatrooms, in pursuit of an FA Cup final-sized audience.
The underlying message, of course, is that itâs very, very wrong to exploit real-life violence as entertainment, a point returned to intermittently between scenes of contestants being impaled, burned alive and blown to pieces. The final-act descent into smug moralism might be easier to take if the movie didnât proceed to contradict itself with one last spectacularly staged killing. The Condemned never quite succeeds in implicating the viewer in the consumption of vio-lent spectacle, although one uncomfortable control-room moment in which the crew can get only a single grainy view of what appears to be a brutal rape-murder successfully mines the aesthetic differences between entertainment and snuff. As for Austin, heâs got a long way to go to be as good as The Rock.

version.name: Captivity
version.review: In this psychological thriller, top fashion model Jennifer Tree (Cuthbert) goes from gracing magazine covers to being locked up in a cell. What follows is a series of blood-curdling torture sequences that only a twisted and sadistic mind can conceive, and receive. Youâve been warned.
version.property: NC16 - No children under the age of 16

version.name: The Blossoming of Maximo Oliveros
version.review:
Dir Auraeus Solito 2005. Philippines. 100 mins. NC16. Nathan Lopez, Soliman Cruz, JR Valentin, Neil Ryan, Ping Medina.
There arenât many love stories about a rookie cop and a 12-year-old boy, but in many ways thatâs what young Filipino director Auraeus Solitoâs debut feature offers. Maxi (Nathan Lopez) is an unapologetically effeminate Manila lad, who gets on surprisingly well with his gangster pa (Soliman Cruz) and street-thug brothers, teasing each other or taking in a DVD in the modest home that Maxi keeps with pride when not swishing fabulously around the slum streets. Tension arrives in the beefy shape of new man on the force, Victor (JR Valentin), who presents Maxi with an appealingly robust model of manhood by determining to overcome the laissez-faire corruption that, problematically, allows his family to thrive. The bond that develops between the two is affectionate and intense enough to get tongues wagging at home and down at the station, where Victorâs zeal is almost as unwelcome as it is on the street. Made on a shoestring with generous help from friends and family, Blossoming is not without its rough edges: Michiko Yamamotoâs script sets up some intriguing conflicts, but comes to a somewhat fumbled climax. But the occasionally handmade feel â hand-drawn credit sequence and all â works to the filmâs benefit. Itâs hard to resist the raucous, vivacious tone encapsulated in its bold, vibrant wardrobe and set dressing and Lopezâs charming and affecting pivotal performance, all of which yield a vivid sense of a capital city rarely seen on screen. Solito also has a cheeky cinephilic sensibility: the haughty chutzpah of the closing homage to The Third Man is worth the admission alone.
version.property: NC16 - No children under the age of 16

version.name: Forest of Death
version.review: Dubbed into Mandarin with Chinese and English subtitles. This Hong Kong horror concerning plant-life with its own sinister intelligence is a solo project by one half of the hardest-working film directors in Asia, the Pang Brothers (see âThe Messengersâ).

version.name: For Your Consideration
version.review: See reviews.

version.name: Transformers
version.review: Based on the hugely popular cartoon and toy range of the 1980s, âTransformersâ revolves around a war between two sets of robots for supremacy on Earth. Optimus Prime is the leader of the Autobots, who have travelled to our planet to protect mankind from Megatron and his evil army of Decepticons. Meanwhile, young human Sam Witwicky buys his first car, which just happens to be Autobot Bumblebee, and finds himself embroiled in the battle to save the planet.

version.name: Spider Lilies
version.review: When webcam girl Jade (Yang) walks into a Taipei tattoo parlor, she meets tattoo artist Takeko (Leong). What they donât realise is that they have a shared past. Filmmaker Zero Chou tells a tale of (lesbian) love, innocence and sexuality found.
version.property: R21 - No one under the age of 21 admitted

version.name: Rescue Dawn
version.review: As brilliant an actor as Christian Bale is, his rapid weight gain and loss makes us worry. In âRescue Dawnâ, the re-emaciated Bale plays a US pilot who struggles to stay alive after being shot down on a mission over Laos during the Vietnam War. Based on a true story.

version.name: Poltergay
version.review: In French with English subtitles. We know itâs OK to be gay, but what if youâre dealing with homosexual-disco-dancing-poltergeists that go bump bump bump in the night? Thatâs what young couple Marc (Cornillac) and his wife Emma (Depardieu) are faced with when they move into a haunted house formerly the site of a 70sâ gay dance club.

version.name: Penelope
version.review: Quixotic Penelope Wilhern (Ricci) is born to a family of wealthy socialites with a long-standing curse. When her familyâs feeble attempt to marry her off to royal blood fails, Penelope takes matters into her own hands and sets out to break the curse. Adventure ensues.

version.name: The Overture
version.review: The film follows musical prodigy Sorn, who remains dedicated to his xylophone-like ranad (a Thai ethnic musical instrument) through the wages of rivalry, romance and world war. The result is plodding but warm-hearted; the music is enchanting and so is the scenery. (Jessica Winter)

version.name: Nancy Drew
version.review: Nancy Drewâs (Roberts) her name and solving mysteriesâ her game. The plot sees the teen detective accompanying her father (Donovan) to Los Angeles for a business trip, only to stumble upon (surprise, surprise) evidence pertaining to a long-unsolved crime involving the mysterious death of a beautiful movie star. If you are a fan of the pulp fiction, then this big-screen adaptation is sure to send you reeling with joy.

version.name: Men in White
version.review: Horror filmmaker Kelvin Tong (who brought you âThe Maidâ in 2005) is back, with a film about the super-superstitious side of life in the Little Red Dot. And if being human in Singapore is hard enough, imagine what itâs like being a ghost. In this film, five Singaporeans are about to find out what it entrails, sorryâ¦entails!

version.name: The Flying Scotsman
version.review: See Review.

version.name: Hooked on You
version.review: In this comedy, 27-year-old Mui (Yeung) finds love in a fish market while working as a fishmonger to pay off her fatherâs debt. When the market closes due to the emergence of mega-stores, she leaves everything behind to embark on a new life overseas as a make-up artist. At the end of the day, Mui finally has an epiphany â what truly matters, is finding that special someone who loves you. Awwwwâ¦

version.name: Fido
version.review: A cloud of âspace dustâ engulfs the earth and turns the dead into flesh-eating zombies. Years later, a scientist invents a special collar that turns the living dead into the house help. Everything is dandy until a next-door neighbour gets eaten.

version.name: Brave Story
version.review: A young boy discovers the way into a fantasy kingdom known as Vision. A series of trials grants him the right to ask a goddess for a wish. His will be to fix his problematic childhood.

version.name: Black Sheep
version.review: This horror-comedy (held from June) is about an experiment in genetic engineering on a farm in New Zealand that goes horribly wrong. B-a-a-a-d.

version.name: Volver
version.review: See Reviews

version.name: Teenage Mutant Ninja Turtles
version.review: Digitally animated revisiting of Kevin Eastmanâs satirical superhero parody about a team of walking, talking sewer-dwelling shell creatures named after Renaissance artists who are blessed with kung fu skills.

version.name: Snow White
version.review: Directed by Iraq-exile and noted documentarist, this is a tale of a rich party girlâs ill-fated romance with a rapper.
version.property: R21 - No one under the age of 21 admitted

version.name: Rocky Balboa
version.review: You know whatâs in store the second the lights go down. Goaded out of retirement for an exhibition round against the current It fighter, Balboa is told to rely on âbrute forceâ. Which is exactly what Stallone does, unleashing greatest-hits moments like H-bombs. Cue Bill Contiâs instantly recognisable theme, commence training montage and start pounding the meat! The actor-director doles out the expected treats in pat populist doses, but that doesnât make this attempt at milking punch-drunk love from the past exciting, just numbingly predictable. (DF)

version.name: The Pursuit of Happyness
version.review: Remember âJust the Two of Usâ, Will Smithâs sensitive man rap paean to fathers and sons on the 1997 album âBig Willie Styleâ? The former Fresh Prince is tugging at similar heartstrings with his new, unfortunately titled movie. Sporting a vintage Jesse Jackson moustache, Smith plays Chris Gardner, a struggling salesman whose wife walks out, leaving him to care for his son (Smithâs real-life progeny, Jaden) even as they slide into homelessness. Despite the canned uplift of this rags-to-riches tale, thereâs something nonetheless affecting about it. (Tom Beer)

version.name: Number 23
version.review: Horror thriller with Carrey in serious mode as a man who finds a book that appears to be about his life

version.name: Notes on a Scandal
version.review: Judi Dench, Cate Blanchett. Though sheâs abetted by Blanchettâs own emotionally volatile portrayal, Denchâs performance is the main attraction in this predatory psychodrama. There isnât much else, really: Eyreâs direction merely plays up the melodramatic aspects of ZoÃ« Hellerâs novel, screenwriter Patrick Marberâs acidic dialogue occasionally slips into the overwritten, and the rest of the cast chews table scraps. (DF)
version.property: M18 - No one under the age of 18 admitted

version.name: Norbit
version.review: Broad comedy vehicle for Murphy, which involves him donning the drag fat-suit yet again

version.name: Music and Lyrics
version.review: Romantic comedy where Hugh Grant plays a has-been pop star teamed up with Drew Barrymore to write a hit song. The two get cosy over the piano and lyric sheets.

version.name: The Messengers
version.review: The Asian powerhouse directing brotherhood of Pang make their debut on American shores in this supernatural thriller about mysterious happenings on a sunflower farm in the midwest.

version.name: The Lives of Others
version.review: See Reviews

version.name: Letters from Iwo Jima
version.review: Since Clint is now taking the Japanese perspective (respectfully and with great curiosity), his latest makes us ask: Was âFlags of Our Fathersâ actually from the American one? Maybe in a fashion. But it seemed more from the perspective of an alien race better known as âPublicitus flackusâ â a film about how wars get sold. âLettersâ, on the other hand, is less timely, a solid war picture, humane, a little dull. There is a certain poetic fatality to siding with the losers, and Eastwood directs some sensitive performances across the language barrier. (JR)
version.property: NC16 - No children under the age of 16

version.name: Just Follow Law
version.review: Jackâs latest, a satire about a fictional branch of the civil service and a body-swapping comedy

version.name: Hannibal Rising
version.review: A fresh attempt to revive serial killing anti-hero Hannibal Lecter by delving into his troubled teens in Europe. No sign of Anthony Hopkins

version.name: Gustave
version.review: Itâs hunt-the-big-monster time when a team heads into the South African jungle on an expedition to capture a 25-foot killer crocodile.

version.name: Ghost Rider
version.review: Another second-tier Marvel comics character gets the action movie treatment. This time heâs a revenge-seeking demonic stunt motorcyclist incarnated by Nic Cage

version.name: Freedom Writers
version.review: Rookie teacher Erin Gruwell (Swank) turned her at-risk students around by giving them journals in which to write about their experiences growing up hard. Itâs an inspiring tale, but LaGraveneseâs movie is a prime example of why filmgoers reflexively wince when they hear the phrase âbased on a true storyâ. A determination to forcefully uplift audiences with emotional cheap shots is one thing, but whatâs unforgivable is the dramatic laziness. Everybody is reduced to caricatures, while the Oscar-winning actor turns the movie into âTo Swank, with Loveâ. (David Fear)

version.name: The Fountain
version.review: Hugh Jackman plays a brilliant, driven surgeon to Rachel Weiszâs gorgeous, suffering wife; he struggles to find a cure for her brain tumour while their cello-scored cryfest is alternately reconfigured as a conquistadorial quest for the Fountain of Youth (also starring Jackman and Weisz) and a far-flung future in which bald yoga devotees get to float in outer space with trees. Clearly the auteur is âLearning to Let Goâ. And when such individuals are allowed to make multimillion-dollar movies with their Oscar-winning girlfriends, you have to wonder if a certain part of the entertainment equation gets left behind. (Joshua Rothkopf)

version.name: Epic Movie
version.review: Assuredly crude film parody from the team that brought us the âScaryâ and âDate Movieâ franchises.

Adaptation of Frank Millerâs comic-strip rendering of the Battle of Thermopylae (when the Persians invaded Greece, 460BC), thatâs been shot entirely against blue screen âSin Cityâ-style to re-create the look of Millerâs and colourist Lyn Varleyâs images

version.name: Zodiac
version.review: See Reviews

version.name: Udon
version.review: Whatâs with the Japanese and food fetishes? On the menu this time, udon. When a man leaves his home country to make it big in New York, he returns defeated and turns to udon to feed his soul â and the rest of the world.

version.name: Turistas
version.review: Josh Duhamel, Melissa George. In fairness, this stink bombâs central idea â sexed-up white tourists preyed upon by scary organ harvesters while on vacation in Brazil â has symbolic resonance in these xenophobic times. Alas, the prevailing intelligence that might have made it a bit more self-aware (Ã la âHostelâ) is AWOL. The real forebears of âTuristasâ are the Italian âcannibalâ films of the 1970s and â80s, wherein white people enter the jungle, display some ugly tendencies and are mercilessly tortured by Amazonians. âTuristasâ keeps the racism and adds a happy ending. (JR)

version.name: To Sir with Love
version.review: Sick of the nauseatingly self-replicating Sadako clones and the formulaic post-âScreamâ teen slasher genre? Hereâs a gory throwback to classic â80s âFriday the Thirteenthâ-style plot structure where a bunch of alumni and their teacher meet for the first time in 16 years at a small class reunion. Of course the happy occasion turns into a nightmare as one by one, they are brutally murdered.

version.name: Summer Palace
version.review: Set against the Tiananmen Square protests of â89, Yu Hong leaves her village, her family and her boyfriend to study in Beijing. There she discovers a world of intense sexual and emotional experimentation when she falls in love with Zhou Wei, a fellow student.

version.name: Retribution
version.review: Detective Yoshioka (Yakusho) heads a serial murder investigation. When the evidence start pointing to him, he begins to wonder whether he may be the very murderer that he is pursuing.

version.name: The Red Cockatoo
version.review: The year is 1961, the year the Berlin Wall went up, and 20-year-old Siggi is just discovering love, freedom and a notorious dance club called âThe Red Cockatooâ

version.name: Provoked: A True Story
version.review: As the title implies, this is based on a true story of a Punjabi woman named Kiranjit Ahluwalia who leaves her hometown in search of marital bliss in London. Once there, sheâs abused by her husband and ends up in prison for murdering the no-good scoundrel

version.name: Premonition
version.review: This misnamed and mediocre thriller marries domestic melodrama and time-travel and paralleluniverse tropes familiar from films like The Jacket, Jacobâs Ladder and Sliding Doors.

version.name: Partition
version.review: A 38-year-old career soldier resigns from the British Indian Army and returns to his childhood village near the border of Pakistan. There, he meets a 17-year-old Muslim girl and takes her under his wing. A latter-day and slightly incestuous Romeo and Juliet set against the backdrop of political and religious upheaval

version.name: Old Garden
version.review: A few months following the Gwangju massacre in the 1980s, a social activist seeks refuge in a mountain village and the arms of his teacher girlfriend. When he leaves to join the student rebellions, heâs arrested almost immediately. Seventeen years later he returns to the woman he loved and abandoned

version.name: Next
version.review: Las Vegas showroom magician Cris Johnson has a deep, dark secret â he can see a few minutes into the future. Using this âgiftâ, he lives off small-time gambling winnings and stays out of trouble. Alas, trouble finds him in the form of agent Callie Ferries who requires his special talents to foil terrorist plans. Nextâ¦

version.name: Nana 2
version.review: Japanese with Chinese and English subtitles. This is the sequel to the hugely successful manga adaptation âNanaâ, about two best friends who share the same name but go different ways in life. Those who enjoyed the first film for its energy both dramatic and musical will be disappointed

version.name: Ming Ming
version.review: Irresistible rogue D (Wu) announces that he will run away with the first woman who can steal $5 million. Ming Ming (Zhou Xun) soon sets about robbing mob boss Cat (Chang) as a means of making that happen.

version.name: Meet the Robinsons
version.review: The timetravelling premise to Disneyâs âJetsonsâ-style sci-fi animation bears a faint resemblance to âBack to the Futureâ, with elements of âThe Terminatorâ thrown in. Itâs a frenetic enterprise, but it does at least address the spectre of adoption in a sensitive way. To date, dweebish orphan Lewis has been through 124 adoption interviews; his propensity for inventing things that go wrong is the reason for his latest rejection

version.name: Lucky You
version.review: When card pro Bana enters the 2003 World Series of Poker, he is pitted against his estranged dad (Duvall). Drew Barrymore co-stars as a Vegas lounge singer. Viva Las Vegas! Or at least Eric Banaâs career. Heâs hot

version.name: Love and Honour
version.review: Takuya Kimura, Rei Dan. Yamadaâs latest offering sees Shinnojo Mimura (Takuya Kimura), a low-ranking samurai in northern Japan in the Edo era, leading a modest but peaceful life, until he is poisoned and loses his eyesight. His wife, Kayo (Rei Dan), goes to ask a higher-ranking official to save his position, but in return, she is sexually harassed. Shinnojo decides to face his senior to save his honour.

version.name: The Last Mimzy
version.review: Two children find a mysterious box containing some outof- this-world devices. Extraordinary things start to happen with they mistake them for toys

version.name: The Last Legion
version.review: When the Roman Empire crumbles, a brave warrior (Firth) travels to Britain in search of a new world and a legion of supporters.

version.name: Jesus Camp
version.review: Documentary. The kids arenât quite all right in this documentary about an evangelical organisation dedicated to turning todayâs preteens into tomorrowâs, Pat Robertsons.

version.name: Infamous
version.review: Toby Jones, Daniel Craig. The idea that tiny, shawl-draped Truman Capote could inspire twin biopics within a year, both of them moody and atmospheric, strains credulity. As it happens, âInfamousâ is not a copycat project, just a victim of unfortunate timing; its script is possibly even more daring than that of âCapoteâ. But the shadow of Philip Seymour Hoffmanâs total transformation looms large, and though Toby Jonesâs swishier performance hardly represents the challenge failed, the new movie is just not distinguished enough to constitute a worthy addition to the myth. Sandra Bullockâs high-school-playaccented Harper Lee doesnât help

version.name: Hula Girls
version.review: Based on a true story, a bunch of Japanese coal minersâ daughters travel halfway across the world to a Hawaiian village to start a hula troupe. Aloha meets Konnichiwa, but not without a struggle.

version.name: The Hills Have Eyes 2
version.review: Itâs confusing when they make sequels to remakes of films that already had sequels, but here it is. Horror-maestro Wes Craven revisits (as writer/producer) his early â80s mutants in the Californian desert shocker one more time

version.name: The Good Shepherd
version.review: De Niroâs sophomore directorial effort condenses the CIAâs long history of dirty tricks into a single spyâs downward spiral. Edward Wilson (Damon) is the sort of Yalie who gets cherry-picked for secret society Skull and Bones and attracts a shrill, shrewish trophy wife (Jolie); heâs also emotionally sealed off enough to pique the interest of the governmentâs new special-ops recruiters. De Niro juggles the myriad bigpicture parts (Cuba, the Congo) with reserved professionalism; itâs the central character, ironically, thatâs the movieâs Achillesâ heel. How can someone sell his soul when you havenât given him a discernible soul in the fist place?

version.name: Fracture
version.review: Hopkins plays a man who is set free after killing his wife in cold blood. Oscar-nominated Canadian born actor Gosling returns after the success of âHalf Nelsonâ as Willy Beachum, an assistant district attorney caught in a cat-and-mouse game with Hopkins

version.name: Check It Out, Yo!
version.review: What do you get when you put a bunch of male high-school chums and rap music together? No, not Dem Franchize Boyz but a light-hearted comedy about impressing the girls. Good enough for two hours worth of mindless entertainment.

version.name: Cadaver
version.review: This cadaver conundrum follows Mai, a medical student who has a scary experience while hands deep in anatomy. After this, a woman ghost who might be the owner of the human shell haunts her

version.name: Breach
version.review: Superbly cast, âBreachâ comes maddeningly close to delivering the seething psychology of the spy game. Not the highstakes- poker spy game, that is, but the nineto- five, hate-my-job spy game. The movieâs notorious subject is Robert Hanssen, an FBI career agent who, it was discovered in 2001, cost America billions in secrets and dozens of lives.

version.name: Blades of Glory
version.review: Two male ice skaters banned from competition find a loophole: they can compete as a pair. This leads, no doubt, to a lot of jokes about straight guys nervous about being perceived as gay.

version.name: Alone
version.review: A woman named Pim and her husband are moving from Thailand to Korea. But when Pimâs mother falls ill and the couple has to go back to Thailand, strange things start to happen in the house where she grew up.

version.name: 28 Weeks Later
version.review: A follow-up to he highly successful â28 Days Laterâ, this orror tale begins six months after the Rage irus annihilated the British Isles, when econstruction of the country is starting. nbeknown to the living, the virus is back for nother round of death.

version.name: Waz
version.review: Well worn by years of gangland brutality, veteran detective Eddie Argo (SkarsgÃ¥rd) prides himself on playing by the book. However, loyalties wane as he and his new rookie partner Helen OâMara (George) find themselves entangled in a string of violent and horrific killings. Opens Apr; date TBC.

version.name: Sunshine
version.review: Boyle has done comedy (âA Life Less Ordinaryâ), horror (â28 Days Laterâ¦â) and even a heartwarming family film (âMillionsâ). Now he tries his hand at sci-fi in this flick about astronauts who fly to the dying sun in an effort to save it and the Earth.

version.name: Shooter
version.review: The plot sounds all too familiar: an ex-marksman living in exile gets conned back into the service only to be set up and forced to go on the run with a nationwide manhunt behind him. The only difference isâ¦ well, there is none. The sucker this time is Bob Lee Swagger (Mark Wahlberg), a former Army sniper who leaves the military after a mission goes bad.

version.name: The Reaping
version.review: Due to the recent death of her family, God-fearing Hilary Swank loses faith and makes it her mission to disprove any and all religious phenomena. But when she arrives at a small Louisiana town that is suffering from what appear to be the Biblical plagues, she realises that maybe science doesnât have all the answers. Will she regain her faith in time to combat the evil forces? Heaven knows.

version.name: Number 23
version.review: Walter Sparrow (Jim Carrey) is just your ordinary dog-catcher until his missus (Virginia Madsen) gives him a curious paperback, âThe Number 23â. As he reads on, itâs like looking inside his head, as the lonely boy protagonist becomes a moody detective, Walterâs own unfulfilled ambition. Soon, however, his fictional alter-egoâs mind-addling obsession with the number 23 leads to kinky sex, suicide and murder. How so? Well, what with birth dates both personal and famous (Shakespeare, Kurt Cobain) totalling the magic numeral, not to mention other âcoincidencesâ, the maddening ubiquity of the number pitches the gumshoe right over the edge, setting up the possibility that the same fate lies in store for Walter. The conceit has a buzz-factor, and an intriguing first half-hour draws us in to the so-called â23 Enigmaâ. But turning this into a workable plot is beyond writer Fernley Phillips, as spiralling events tumble into inconsequentiality, and gestures towards moral seriousness prove ill-founded. (Trevor Johnston). In cinemas now.

version.name: Cages
version.review: Family drama set in suburban Singapore. See Also opening. In cinemas now.

version.name: Because I Said So
version.review: Could someone please stage a Diane Keaton intervention? This terrific actor must be steered toward better material (admittedly the Holy Grail for ladies of a certain age in Hollywood these days). Directors? Please exercise some restraint with Ms Keaton; less is always more. And while weâre at it, how about a moratorium on playing nightmare moms? Everyone here is a caricature, and the gaps are papered over with hyperactive shtick. I havenât seen so many cakes dropped or smashed since âI Love Lucy.â (Tom Beer) In cinemas now.

version.name: Awake
version.review: 22-year-old Clay Beresford (Christensen) has it all: money, power, business savvy, daddy issues, bum ticker. But life at the top stops for no one a donor heart comes through, and Clay defies his widowed mothers (Olin) slick-surgeon recommendation, entrusting his friend (Howard) with the cutting. Sam Lockwood (Alba), Clays hottie-bo-bottie lady, remains dutifully by his side despite his mothers disapproval. Surgery begins; Clays awake and unable to move, but he sure as hell feels pain. Harolds film contains more than enough that being more than none of the ensuing mind-screams (Hey! Im awake! Aaaaah! That hurts!!! is nearverbatim), and the conspiracy theory against Clay, which he overhears while under the knife, is painstakingly predictable. Still, we cant deny the flick a few surprises along the way, even if we have to suffer through Christensens Anakin Skywalker-on-Valium existence. (Steve Heisler)

version.name: Are We Done Yet?
version.review: A sequel to 2005âs âAre We There Yet?â, Nick (Cube) finds himself in yet another sticky family situation when an eccentric contractor does more than just fix the roof.

version.name: The Hitcher
version.review: See Reviews. In cinemas now.

version.name: 13 Tzameti
version.review: Black & white. In French and Georgian with English subtitles. See Reviews. In cinemas now.
version.property: NC16 - No children under the age of 16

version.name: The Namesake
version.review: See Reviews.

version.name: Alpha Dog
version.review: Were only a few months in to 2007, and already weve got a solid contender for the worst movie of the year: Nick Cassavetess cruddy Alpha Dog. Smuggled into theatres a year after it closed the Sundance Film Festival, Alpha Dog is based on the true story of Jesse James Hollywood, a rich Southern Californian creep who was one the youngest people ever on the FBIs mostwanted list.Sybaritic, monosyllabic, wealthy adolescent Angelenos play at being baddies, led by head cretin Johnny Truelove (Hirsch). Meth-addled Jake (Foster) hasnt paid Johnny the dollars he owes him, so he kidnaps Jakes kid brother with the help of henchman Frankie (Timberlake). Treading disastrously on the teenage wasteland already fetishised in a million Larry Clark movies, Alpha Dog scratches its balls and sniffs its own butt, cynically playing its noxious characters and story line as rough indie cred. Even Clarks prurience toward his dead-end kids is far nobler than Cassavetess pathetic slumming in thug life.Note to Timberlake: nine-minute music videos are far kinder to your talents than a feature-length movie. But then again, even those performers born before the Reagan administration cluelessly endure their ignominies: Bruce Willis with bad hair plugs, Sharon Stone in a fat suit, Harry Dean Stanton with a potty mouth. Alpha Dog will leave you reaching for the beta-blockers.
version.property: R21 - No one under the age of 21 admitted

version.name: The Dead Girl
version.review:
A clutch of overwrought vignettes linked by the death of a prostitute at the hands of a serial killer, âDeadâ opens with the wonderful Collette doing that mousy, repressed thing that unimaginative casting directors see as her raison dâÃªtre. Hag-ridden by her shrewish mom (Laurie, recycling all her bits fromâCarrieâ but the phrase âdirty pillowsâ), she takes a walk, fi nds the corpse and reports it. The creep who bags her groceries (Ribisi) recognises her from the TV news, and they return to the crime scene for unwholesome sex.
The subsequent chapter features Byrne as a forensic technician whose yen for closure feeds her hope that the dead girl will turn out to be her missing sister. The baton next goes to Hurt, unrecognisably dowdy as a nagging wife who discovers that her husband (Searcy) is a bigger heel than she ever imagined. Next up is Harden as the deceasedâs mother, belatedly seeking to understand how her girl went so wrong and fi nding the standard explanatory skeleton in the family closet. Rounding out the bill is Murphy as the doomed hooker, whoâs trying to do right by her toddler daughter.
Harrowing in an off-the-rack kind of way, âDeadâ is to female victimhood what âCrashâ was to racism, minus (to its credit) the shiny uplift.

version.name: The Town
version.review: Based on the Chuck Hogan novel The Prince of Thieves, this taut, gritty Boston-set crime thriller sees Affleck as the unswerving career thief who falls for one of his bank-heist victims with the FBI in hot pursuit.
version.property: M18 - No one under the age of 18 admitted

version.name: Takers
version.review: A suited, hip-hopping team of white-collar bank heisters meet their match in Matt Dillons badass leather-voiced LA detective Jack Welles.

version.name: The Social Network
version.review: Based of the The Accidental Billionaires by Ben Mezrich, the long-waited biopic of Harvard dropout cum internet billionaire and Facebook co-founder Mark Zuckerberg with Jesse Eisenberg as the embattled super-nerd.

version.name: Paranormal Activity 2
version.review: Sequel to the super-bankable box-office smash continues the found footage-style of the 2009 horror, with the supernatural goings-on continuing in young couple Katie and Micahs home.
version.property: NC16 - No children under the age of 16

version.name: Oceans: Into the Deep
version.review: 3D documentary tracing a sea turtles eventful odyssey across the ocean.

version.name: Lottery Ticket
version.review: Poor kid (Bow Wow) wins big in the lotto, with Atlanta projects thugs in pursuit of his millions. Dismal.

version.name: Life As We Know It
version.review: Comedy-drama with an unlikely, chalk-and-cheese couple (Heigl and Duhamel) are thrust into parenthood when their mutual pals die unexpectedly and leave a sprog in their care.

version.name: Let Me In
version.review: Based on Swedish novelist John Ajvide Lindqvis Let the Right One In, director Matt Cloverfield Reeves New Mexico-set remake of the 2008 Tomas Alfredson film of the same name sees bullied 12-year-old boy Owen (Smit-McPhee) develop a friendship with a young female vampire trapped in eternal youth.

version.name: The Incite Mill
version.review: The Ring directors latest pycho-thriller sees ten people who reply to a job ad end up forced to take part in a seven-day death game where only two will survive.
version.property: NC16 - No children under the age of 16

movie.name: The Girl Who Kicked the Hornetâs Nest

version.name: The Girl Who Kicked the Hornetâs Nest
version.review: The final part of the brutal Steig Larsson trilogy, Salander (Rapace) must prove her innocence in her trail of attempted murder with the help of journo Mikael Blomkvist.
version.property: NC16 - No children under the age of 16

version.name: Flipped
version.review: Mushy 1950s-set tween rom-com about a smitten mismatched couple philosophical Juli (Carroll, 14) and shy Bryce (McAuliffe, 15) falling in love in eighth grade.

version.name: The American
version.review: Dutch director probably best known for his stylish Joy Division biopic Control returns with this broody, noir-ish thriller with Clooney as the lone assassin hiding out in an Italian forest on one last fraught assignment.
version.property: R21 - No one under the age of 21 admitted

version.name: Scott Pilgrim vs. the World
version.review:
With its short attention span, graphic-novel source material, video-game structure, deep-tracks pop-culture references and affectless hero whose geeky exterior conceals a gooey, sentimental core, Scott Pilgrim may be the perfect distillation of the early-twentysomething zeitgeist circa 2010.Thats the good news and also the bad news. Bass-playing, jobless slacker Scott (Cera) falls for Ramona Flowers (Winstead), whose purple locks and cool demeanour at least make a nice change from the usual manic-pixie dream girl. She also has some baggage, in the form of her seven evil exes, whom Scott must battle if he wants to date her. Wright chops the screen up into multiple pieces in a nod to Bryan Lee OMalleys comic-book style and fills that screen with pop-up information and animated add-ons (little pink hearts explode from a kiss, a telephone emits the word ring when it rings). While the style is frantic, the characters remain numb and distracted, as if theyre waiting for a tweet about an impromptu party somewhere. For a while, that blend of jittery caffeination and sleepy hipster cool is charming, but soon it becomes exhausting. Puzzlingly, Wright doesnt do enough to differentiate the battles. The first ex (Bhabha) makes a few nods to his Indian heritage, and Evans does some droll stuff as a movie star, but for the most part, the battles look and feel the same; I found myself keeping count so I knew how many were yet to come.
That could be forgiven if Scott were someone we could care about, but Cera is the wrong man for the job. Yes, Scotts meant to be a bit of a self-centred drip, but Cera is the kind of drip that makes you call for a plumber. Hank Sartin

version.name: Dinner for Schmucks
version.review:
Populist screenwriter Francis Veber (La Cage aux Folles) may be Frances longtime king of odd-couple farce, but the broad humour of his films rarely translates to Hollywood (see or, rather, dont see Fathers Day, Pure Luck and The Man with One Red Shoe).
In the only sporadically entertaining Dinner for Schmucks, director Jay Roach (Meet the Fockers) takes on Vebers mean-spirited 1998 comedy The Dinner Game, about Parisian publishing pals who invite eccentric idiots to a meal before mockingly awarding the most exceptional guest.
Outside of the specifically Gallic brand of condescending intellectualism, the Americanised version reconfigures the plot as both a hazing ritual for corporate ladder-climbers and a lazy hook to hang cheap jokes on. Private equity analyst Tim Conrad (Rudd) makes the right play at a staff meeting and is given the preliminary nod to a bump upstairs. First, though, he must attend the titular mansion party thrown by his boss. Briefly hesitating when his almost-fiancée Julie (Szostak) chastises him in moral disapproval, Tim motors ahead and nearly runs over oblivious IRS drone Barry (Carell).
The perfect companion for such a cruel soirée, Barry is a self-delusional, literal-minded simpleton whose innocent intentions become burdensome by the fact that he cant take a hint. Once Tim is shackled to this deep-down loveable caricature, the mismatched buddy shtick with a tender resolution is on autopilot.
The cast is effortlessly wittier than the sitcom-grade material theyre supplied with, especially supporting funnymen Zach Galifianakis, David Walliams and Jemaine Clement the last as an insatiable, self-important art star who might be equal parts Julian Schnabel and Russell Brand. Aaron Hillis

version.name: The Last Exorcism
version.review: An evangelical minister takes part in a documentary to perform his last exorcism on a possessed Louisiana country girl in this savagely gripping, Eli Roth-produced found footage-style horror-thriller.
version.property: NC16 - No children under the age of 16
